How have I lived here all of these months and not given a shout out to my local bread, pizza, and coffee shop?!?! Certainly a triad of yummy-ness! I have certainly been remiss in my duties as a loyal customer! Like everyone has said, the breads are fantastic and the pizzas are yummy. 

Cash only so plan accordingly. 

Someone let me know how the pastries are these days. I'm afraid to try one for fear it will go straight to my hips. It's too short of a walk home to justify consumption :(
author: Lisa J.

description: Corn-cherry scone = jizz in my pants andy samberg style
author: Paran Y.

description:
what i ordered... pecan roll

pecan roll was good, lots of pecan and good in size if you pick the right one that is.

ambiance... good(tiny place but has a cute lounging area at the sidewalk)
service... so-so(the dude at the cashier was yapping and yapping and yapping with his co-worker while taking customers payment)
cost... $
author: Gors P.

description:
Pretty consistent with the delicious pastries.

My two favorite pastries are:

- chocolate roll/bun
- raspberry/blueberry scone

They also give you a discount if you come one your bicycle (probably should bring your helmet in so they know you ride)
author: Patrick P.

description:
I'm not from here and not really into that co-op local schtuff but damn this place is good. 

Grabbed a pecan roll to take home. Just ate it two days later, and it's still yummers. The goo is like candy! Unfortunately after I had picked out my roll and paid, they brought out a fresh new tray. Try to get the largest, stickiest one you can find. The dough is so rich. mmm

As for the pizza, I was stuffed from earlier and didn't eat it onsite. I forgot which toppings of the day it was. Next day we retoasted it and it was really, really good. I'd say it's on par with a sit-down high end place like Pizza Mozza but totally unpretentious cuz you got it at Arizmendi. It was a white pizza with leafy greens, garlic, and tiny shots of goat cheese. I liked that in every bite you got a new ingredient and the goat cheese did not overpower at all. It was torture waiting for it to reheat. 

Like Escape from NY it was thin yet doughy. Good and greasy enough from the cheese. The best part is the dough is sourdough! Or I think. 

I will definitely be coming back to any location in the city. This pizza made me like pizza in SF. 

P.S. The other bread rolls in the case looked very legit. I used to work in a bakery so take my word.
author: Audrey L.

description: Great daily pizzas, almost as good as cheese board in Berkeley.
author: Monica R B.

description:
Arizmendi, your pizza rocks just as much as your name and I love you in so many ways that I'm often left speechless, usually after my first bite nomnomnom.. mmm nomnomnom mmmm... 
This co-op produces amazing pizzas, and they sell a slice for only $2.25, and by half and whole pizzas for take out or bring home and bake. Only one kind of pizza a day. I've trekked over to the inner sunset so many times just to get a slice of pizza. I usually chill on the abandoned wooden bench across the street, and just savor every bite. Dude.. the crust is thin, crispy, and sourdoughy, cheese is gooey with perfect touch of saltiness and the toppings are always fresh and aromatic.  Such ghetto gourmet heaven!  My favorite is anything pizza with mushrooms.. but they've got tons of other goodies as well, scones, breads, sweets, and treats, all worth trying.  

*Miss Piggy's stamp of approval*
author: Miss Pigg y.

description:
As BF & I were enjoying a superbly sunshine-filled lunch of shiitake, button mushroom, smoked mozzarella, garlic, oil, parsley, & parmesan on thin-crust sourdough pizza (mmm, sourdough pizza crust), a blonde, ruddy 11-yr-old walks up to the door.

"Mommy! Look!" He pointed excitedly at the specials board.

The weary-looking brunette glanced over.

"Cherry-chocolate sourdough scones! Ooh....yum....nom nom...ohhhh" he starts to rub his belly and groan. 

"Not today, we gotta keep walking," she says.

The little boy makes a face like his pet has just died. "But, ohh...cherry chocolate sourdough!" 

Bet he's still thinking about them. And maybe posting on CL Missed Encounters.

Rockin' hippie pizza and a bakery that gets a little boy who should only care about soccer and cartoons excited about pastries? Five stars well-deserved.
author: Gloria L.

description: I don't know what else to say... Their daily pizza is out of this world delicious.
author: Jessica H.

description:
FINALLY made it out here & it's totally worth it!

On a weekday morning, took a seat to enjoy our pastries... sadly though I didn't realize they only start making the daily pizza @ 11:30 :(
(oh well, another reason to come back ;)

++ Corn cherry scone: LOVE the texture, like a cookie, but not overly dry, cherrys are subtle, crumbly, so catch the crumbs!
+ Strawberry blue scone: great flavor, more of a moist scone
++ Cheese roll: simple, perfect, friends said it was like mac n' cheese
++ Asiago tomato focacccia- crisp, chewy, flavor packed
++ Olive focaccia- so aromatic!! (same as above)
+Corn blueberry muffin: MUFFIN TOP was huge, and that just made this even better.

 I love great bakeries.
author: Angel L.

description:
Corn Cherry Scone and coffee was amazing.  Also, great location next to Golden Gate Park was perfect!  Get some pastries and coffee and walk over to the park for a morning picnic.  I took one star off since service and focaccia bread were four stars.

We will for sure be back to try more!
author: Bridget H.

description:
Why won't they open one of these bakeries in the South Bay?  

I've loved this sister bakery to the Cheeseboard ever since it opened up in my old nabe years ago.  I was so excited that I could get cheese rolls, yummy pizzas, chocolate things, foccaccia, and scones without schlepping across the bay.  

Whenever my husband is in the neighborhood, I always ask him to pick up a lite-baked pizza that we can heat at home (along with a bunch of other baked goodies).  They make my favorite take out pizzas because the toppings are always great and the crust crisps up perfectly in my own oven.  Mmmm mmmm good.
author: Michelle T.

description:
I LOOOOVEEEE this bakery!! Whenever you pass by this bakery, there's always lots of people outside of it just chilling, eating their scones or their slice of pizza.  PIZZA?!! in a bakery?!  YES.  In fact, it's one of best pizzas ever!!  They sell it by the slice for $2/slice.  Each day is a new pizza, combos different from any other pizza place.  Well worth it I say.  Their scones are super GOOD.  Initially, I hated scones because my first scone was from Starbucks, and it was dry and gross.  But after tasting Arizmendi's scones, I am forever a fan as long as its from here.  They have interesting combos like blueberry and corn, but it's soooo good!  Scones are about $2.75 each.  They also have a large variety of breads and other pastries.  

This place is just sooo good.  I'm glad it's right down the street from me. =)
author: Diane L.

description:
I HAVE to go there if I'm near the city.  Sometimes I have to go there a couple times during the same trip.  Their pizza is damn delicious. Their pastries and breads and moist and fresh and perfect.  Their scones are fab.  Their shortbread cookies are addicting.  
 
AND they're open on Sundays!
author: Missy W.

description: Amazing sourdough bread, focaccias and pizzas!
author: Sid R.

description: The most amazing brioche I've ever had! I had one of the savory pastries, scone of the day, brioche and my sister had strawberry coffee cake over three or four visits. This is a bakery that does it right. They are efficient and provide a quality delicious product. It's obvious why there's always a line out the door. I bet the fresh pizza is amazing too. I will definitely be back for that. I love the outdoor benches too. This is a worker owned coop too so you can feel really extra good about supporting them.
author: Amanda R.

description:
You want to acheive BFF status with me?  Show up with Arizmendi baked goods in a brown paper bag, on a Sunday morning after an epic Saturday night.  Tear off morsels of bialy slathered in caramelized onions and poppy seeds and feed them to me, one savory chewy piece at a time.  Utterly delicious.  Open the bag to show me a glimpse of something with pecans and cinnamon inside, while I sip tea and slowly rejoin the human race.  

A brown bag with baked goods followed by promises of more baked goods. Therin lies the key to my heart.
author: Liz S.

description:
From the other reviews here, i wish i got the pizza.  

Came on a sunday afternoon, when the farmers market across the street was going on.  The place was kinda a cluster.  A couple families with kids running back and forth between the different cabinets of baked goods made it kinda difficult to get around.  After all that though, i got several types of focaccia which were both very good, ginger shortbread which was very tasty, and the corn and cherry scone which is every bit as excellent as others have said.  Kinda wish i also got the chocolate/mint cookie, which looked really good.
author: Phil J.

description:
Yum Yum Yum
Our favorite was the Coffee Cake (apple blueberry I think) and it was extremely moist and still warm when we ate it.  The Blueberry Pluot Scone had huge pieces of fruit in it so it made the scone (which can be rather dry) quite moist as well.  Although unexpected, the corn-cherry scone was surprisingly tasty as well. I was overwhelmed with the amazing smells coming from inside and would love to return (many many times) to try everything.
**Cash Only so stop by a bank on the way **
author: Tonia D.

description: Pastries are super fresh and delicious. They have a few good vegan options (cookies) which is great.  It would be nice if they would accept credit cards though. A few times I ordered something for my kids before realizing that I don't have cash on me.
author: Flora O.

description: Im wasn't really impressed with arizmendi's bakery.  While there was a line out the door for this place, I thought it would be amazing.  The pizza that they were serving looked really good but we just had lunch.  So I picked up a brand muffin, chocolate chip cookie and a pecan roll.  The cookie wasn't very good.  Took two bites and made the decision that its not worth the calories.  My wife said the brand muffin was good but not great.  Maybe the pizza is good here cause everyone was eating it but as far as what I had, I was not impressed.
author: Henry S.

description:
CAN WE SAY AMAZING!!!!!!!!!!!! 

Arizmendi is my kind of place.. they make one pizza all day every day, and make it delicious....the crust is good, the sauce is not too heavy, the ingredients they choose for each type of pizza is perfectly harmonized with the smell of tastiness :) yes... it's that good.....and don't think you'll have to pay a lot for this amazing slice... you can get it by the slice which after tax is only a whooping $2.00 hell m f'n yes!!! please sign me up :) 

btw their baked goods are to die for.!!!! english muffins that remind me more of a bagel then a english muffin that stays fresh for a couple of days! hell yes.. WHO WANTS AN EGG'S BENEDICT VIA NINA!! who wants it!!!!
author: Nina M.

description: I came here with my friend and I was pleasantly surprised. We came at the end of the day and ordered our pizza and a few pastries (more like 6 of them). We had the mushroom, roasted zucchini, goat cheese and thyme oil pizza, which was awesome. I l liked our pastries, however, I've definitely had better. I'm also being critical of this place because Cheeseboard in Berkeley  (associated with Arizmendi) is the best I've ever had and I really loved the freshness of Cheeseboard so much more. The people were a little nicer and there is live music there too. Overall, Arizmendi is a solid place to go to for some good veggie pizza, but Cheeseboard is better.
author: Sheeva G.

description:
I can't take my mind off of Arizmendi Bakery.  Was walking home from work and was starving.  Walked in here for the first time after seeing it a million times and I kind of have bittersweet feelings about this place.  I effing love EVERYTHING I've ever bought from here, but my waist ain't havin' it.  :(  Cheese, butter, carbs.  Who could turn that down??? Siiiiigh.

Anyway, rosemary parmesan scone, pecan roll, and cheese roll are the things I've had so far and let me tell you... they make my eyes roll to the back of my head and run a few laps before they go back to normal again.  I wanted to try a scone to see if they were dry so I picked up the first one I saw.  To my surprise, it was moist, salty and cheesy from the parmesan, slightly herby from the rosemary, and perfectly flakey with a slight light crispiness around the surface.  The pecan roll was not too sweet with the perfect amount of toasted pecans and a slight taste of maple.  Have you ever bought cheesebread to be disappointed because you can't really taste the cheese?????  WELL, the cheese roll thing will make you happy!  It's cheesy, crusty, chewy, and satisfying!  BEST PART-During baking, the cheese oozes out and finds its way down to the bottom of the roll and hardens so a cheesy crust forms. YUMMMM  

Arrite, I need to go there in the morning.  Cookie bark is what I was eyebalin last time.  I hear pizza is good too.  If you're ever in the area, DO NOT forget to fulfill your carb intake of the......year.
author: Cheryl Q.

description: Yum. Thank goodness I do not live near this bakery, otherwise I would be 10 pounds heavier. For an occassional treat, this bakery has great options.
author: Jolie S.

description:
Now that we finally moved to the fog, we're indulging in the 'Zmendi a lot more often.  

Everything is good, but here are the standouts:

* CORN CHERRY SCONES and the CHEESE SCONES - they have a special scone everyday but they are rarely as good as these standbys
* BREADSTICKS - great snack for walking around the farmer's market
* my man is obsessed with the CHOCOLATE THINGS.  i am not a chocolate lover - to me, they taste like challah with choc chips
* TWO WORDS - CHEESE ROLLS
* HOMEMADE PIZZA that makes even the Pickiest East Coast Pizza Purist smile
author: Melissa Y.

description: MMMmm...good pastry and pizza. Everything is fresh and looks delish. A bit pricey to me but its definitely worth it. Great to grab a few of these goods for a picnic. Careful not to go overboard! I had to restrain myself since it was a late lunch.
author: Luna L.

description: Delish, delish, delish.  Excellent customer service, except: the lines are long and there is little parking to speak of in the neighborhood.  The latter isn't unusual, so just take Muni or plan enough time to park several blocks away if need be.  But I feel there could be two people helping up front more often.  It's almost always been only one person at the cash register.  Oh: their pizza is OUT of this world so stop by for a lunchtime slice.
author: Amber G.

description:
Four words: Nom, nom, nom, nom.

For those who live or work close by to Arzimendi Bakery, I envy you.  Every time I walk into this bakery, the aroma of baked goods creates a priceless moment.  I feel so giddy, wondering what my taste buds and stomach desires.

With a variety of delicious artisan bread, gourmet pizza, and pastries, the selection is sure to please even the toughest critics.  Plus, the staff is friendly and energetic.

Located in Inner Sunset, this bakery has a schedule in making certain bread and pizza.  For the Super Bowl on Feb 1, Triple Mushroom with a Sesame-Ginger-Garlic Vinaigrette Pizza will be offered and is a must try.

My favorites include their Irish Soda Bread, Garlic-Herb Sourdough, Wolverines, Cheese Bread, Bread Sticks, Currant Scones, Artichoke Focaccia, and Pecan / Cheese Rolls.

The coffee is also very good, so you can skip Starbucks across the street.

Room for improvement:  
- Please open on Mondays.
- Please have a terminal to accept debit/credit cards.
- Please think of starting another bakery in San Francisco with a parking lot.

***

Why does 13 not 12 make up a baker's dozen?  Where did the +1 come from?

Here are three theories with the first being most probable:

A.  Since bread was common food for the masses in the medieval times, it was considered a crime if any baker cheated the consumers by selling them underweight.  Bread, at that time, was sold by weight rather than the actual count.  So if the baker threw in an extra loaf of bread, then the baker would be clear of any wrongdoing.  Urban legend claimed the punishment resulted in the chopping of an ear or a hand.

B.  There were middlemen involved in helping the bakers sell the bread.  For every 12 pieces sold, the baker threw in one as a freebie.

C.  The baker made an extra piece as tasting sample for the consumers.

These theories, however, are unpopular today because the number 13 is an odd and an unlucky number.  Besides, twelve pieces fit better in a box than thirteen.

As an exercise, you can use the freshly baked sourdough as a pair of mittens.  Just tear it in half and make your thumbs stick out.  Wash your hands first though if you plan to eat it later.



      (((((((((((((((((((((((
   ((
((
   ((
      (((((((((((((((((((((((
author: CT L.

description:
Hi my name is Dave, and I'm a brioche-knot-aholic.
-Hi Dave!

That about sums it up. More specifically, my idea of a perfect Saturday morning is grabbing a brioche knot and a cup of coffee from Arizmendi and walking down 9th Ave. into Golden Gate Park, wandering into the Botanical Gardens, finding a park bench in a secluded grove of exotic greenery and indulging in the soft, fluffy, slightly sweetened handful of heaven.  This bakery is good, I've tried a number of things with standouts being about everything. But for about a month now, the only thing I can buy there is a brioche knot. For a week or two I had to have one every day. Who knows what I could become addicted to next if I just branched out to the chocolate things or the pecan rolls... Excuse me while a grab a towel to wipe the drool off of my laptop.
author: Dave F.

description: We love this bakery!  Every time we go to SF, we make sure we get to go to Arizmendi's - it's that good.  Everything is fresh, and the prices are good.  They only accept cash, so come prepared.
author: Julia E.

description:
I've always been a fan of Cheeseboard in Berkeley so of course I had to try its sister co-op Arizmendi in Emeryville and this past Sunday, the location in the city. I have to say Cheeseboard does have a little extra somethin' going on. The Berkeley location is split up, devoting a store to selling just the pizzas right next to its cheese and bake shop so I guess that makes it seem more special. Maybe it's just a mental thing... 

But, I'm happy to say Arizmendi has its own charm and character. We always order a whole pizza, no matter what their pizza of the today is so we can enjoy eating delicious pizza all day long. We've never been disappointed even though the toppings aren't up to us. They pleasantly surprise me everytime I go in with toppings that are season and at the peak of flavor. This past Sunday it was tomatoes, arugula, gorgonzola cheese, garlic oil, and fresh basil. I never thought I could enjoy veggie pizza, until I tastes theirs. The bread and ingredients are always so fresh and flavorful, you don't even notice that there isn't meat. 

I want to try the savory baked goods but I always end up with more dessert-ish pastries: scones, cookies, and short breads. The snickerdoodle cookie always hits the spot after some cheesy almost good for you pizza but the coconut shortbread is my favorite! They have crispy coconut flakes throughout the buttery and rich short bread. Just thinking about it makes my mouth water! It's the best after dinner dessert while with some black tea. 

When I was up to pay, I completely forgot it was cash only. I had one bill, a Jackson but I was still short. I was really embarrassed and about to put the cookies back but the sympathetic cashier said "it's okay, just bring back $1.50 next time." I know $1.50 is practically nothing but his sincere trust completely made my day. ;)
author: Julia T.

description: The corn blueberry muffin is basically my only reason for living. Or at least the best reason.
author: Lola S.

description:
Where else can you get a price cut on your amazing pizza and pastry for riding your bike? Arizmendi, that's where.

Arizmendi is amazing for so many different reasons, but here is what is especially amazing about them - at least from my knowledge:

Pizza -
 Dig it - it's thin crust with fantastic toppings. I especially love it when they have the pizza with shitake mushrooms and the sesame ginger garlic vinaigrette. For your pizza loving soul, make sure to check out the pizza of the day on their site so you can venture there on the day when your soul is most likely to meet that special 'whoever thought of putting cheese on bread in the size of a triangle was a genius' moment. 

Chocolate Chip Cookies -
They're so gooey it's like I'm five again. The chocolate bleeds from the sweet morsel and gets all over my hands it's so fresh and tasty!

The Pecan Roll -
Hello god, it's me Alex. I know you are not conspiring to get me fat, I believe you, but whenever I take a bite of the pecan roll at Arizmendi I start to second guess your good intentions. Don't blame me, blame Arizmendi. 

Location - 
Well, Alex, if you're so worried about getting fat why don't you take a walk in Golden Gate park - which is right near Arizmendi - and make sure that pecan roll doesn't go straight to your gut. 

Until next time - when I eat even more - that's a wrap.
author: Alexandra M.

description:
I LOOVEEE ARIZMENDI~!

I work near this bakery. So on certain days when I have time to kill before work, I would stop by and grab some of their yummy pastries to buy and enjoy. Being the fact that there are no "artificial" ingredients in their products only makes the food taste even better.

Muffins...good
Cookies...yummy. Even their vegan cookies are awesome!
Savory ones like foccacias and breadsticks, they're alright.
Their daily pizza? For $2.25 a slice, they are small with no meat, but it is so delicious that you may forget all about the meat.

Their bakery goods are so awesome, I would not be surprised if I gained weight because of the amount I eat.

Yummy Yummy...i want some of their pizzas now...

CASH ONLY. They do take $100 bills.
author: Kim L.

description: LOVE THIS BAKERY!!!  They have such a unique assortment of tasty pastry from sweets to salty, there is certainly something to please everyone's palate.  I love to come here in the morning where everything is super fresh.  The pizza is really tasty too, and at $2.50 it is really a deal.  The only problem with the pizza is that sometimes the slices are inconsistent, getting a big or small slice is the luck of the draw.  The service is just okay but I think the food makes up for it.
author: Eva E.

description:
I never knew bread could taste so heavenly.

but their focaccia with basil and cheese was absolutely good.  It's almost like you have to call it someting besides bread, because its not simply just bread.  

And believe me, when you get the bread in a paperbag, you may at first feel disgusted by the oil that's showing up on the bag and making the paper clear, but once the aroma hits you, you'll probably just sucker and take a bite and hate yourself for not taking one earlier because now its 5 minutes past and its not as warm as it was before.
author: Vincent K.

description: their fresh pizza was soo goood! too bad I only ordered one! their blueberry scones were good too!
author: L E.

description:
i fell in love with their blueberry & corn cherry scones!!!  it is perfectly baked/sweetened and the flavor is delicious!!!

[PRICE]
blueberry scone: $2.50
corn cherry scone: $2.25

also, their today's pizza was simply scrumptious. it was filled with mushrooms, asago cheese, rosemary oil, parsley & Parmesan!!! 

[PRICE]
slice:  $2.25
1/2 of pizza:  $8.99
whole pizza: $18

i got the 1/2 of pizza & the amount was very satisfying. :D

hooray for a place that has pizza & baked goodies! ^_^
author: Deborah C.

description: Best Bay Area bakery ever.  I approach the pizza board each visit with excitement.  The cheese rolls are amazeballs
author: Kabir S.

description:
The great majority of my Arizmendi runs are squeezed between doing laundry or right before catching the N-Judah, so that means I've never actually sat down and enjoyed my pizza/pastry/bread on site until recently. 

With the economic downturn, I'm now experiencing what I call "No Work Wednesdays". Last week I learned that Wednesdays in the middle of the day is the prime time to truly enjoy this place, with no lines, no crowds, but still a steady flow of customers and pedestrians to people watch. I took advantage of this day to wait around for a piping hot slice of pizza topped with artichoke, feta, and garlic oil fresh out of the oven. It was hands-down the best slice $2.25 has ever gotten me.

For that slice alone it would get 5 stars, but the pizza of the day changes daily and it's not always a winning combination. Anything with artichokes is 5 stars. Anything with spinach or arugula is 3 stars. Mushrooms, olives, or sun-dried tomatoes are a toss-up from okay to really good. If you're in the neighborhood it's posted on the sidewalk sign. The website also posts the daily special, but sometimes the website lies and you'll find this out in-person, so don't count on this.
author: Victoria N.

description: If you haven't been here already, just go!  You will not regret it, in fact, you will absolutely love it;-)  I tried their Banana Bran Muffin, Corn Cherry Scone and their Marinated Artichoke Hearts/Spinach/Basil pizza and nothing else I've ever had from any bakery here in SF even compares.  Love their pizza - it is truly one of, if not THE best in SF.  The guy who rang up my order was very nice and all smiles;-)  Would definitely go back here again when I can - I went around 2pm on a Saturday and there was a line to the door, but being how tasty their stuff is, that's quite understandable!  I can't wait to try more of their stuff as I'm sure it's all very good!!
author: Kahanalei M.

description:
Holy Smokes!  The cherry corn scone was delicious.  $2.25 for the scone.  Crystal sugars, the corn flavor, delicious.  A little messy to eat as it crumbles.  Best had with their coffee.  Note that the small coffee is, well, small.  Small coffee $1.25.  

Cash only folks!!! 

I will definitely be back and would be a regular if I lived closer.  The N-Judah stops right in front of it too - how convenient :)
author: Alias A.

description:
First time there on Wednesday. i know, I've lived in the city all my life and pass by it how many times. Well, I finally made the step.

The aroma is intoxicating, I know they do that on purpose to get people in their bakery. 

Pizza bread! Yummy! forget the Victor's Bakery pizza bao/bread. This pizza bread is 5.25/lb. Huge piece, maybe 5" x 5" and thick with tomatoes and other spices. As i reached in to get it I didn't know what I was expecting, but my first reaction, "It's still warm!" Like it had a warmer in there or something. That bread was goooooood. 

I accidentally took a bite out of it, they go my weight there. That big piece of pizza goodness only cost $2.75. What a steal! 

I restrained myself from getting anything else, I need to limit my carb intake. I will be stepping in there more often.

If I'm ever hungry and I'm around there, a great place to get something and not over stuff yourself.
author: Leanne K.

description:
Sweet jesus, the pizza is awesome! I'm a huge fan of the 1/2 baked pizzas that you can finish in your own oven. They turn out great!

I just wish I lived closer - I would be here once a week without a doubt.

I don't follow cooking the instructions on the box bc I dont like drippy cheese mess in the oven (which would happen with 1/2 a pizza with cut edge). Stick a cookie sheet in the oven, preheat to 450 and put your pizza on the cookie sheet when the oven is up to temp. It only needs about 5-8 minutes for a nicely crisp crust and hot bubbly cheese! YUM!
author: Shal J.

description:
Everything about this place is amazing. 
Good coffee. 
The blueberry coffee cake is awesome, as is the pumpkin muffins (although they don't always have the muffins).
The chocolate cake with salted caramel icing...oh my...dangerous. 
The pizza changes daily and is always delicious and an interesting blend of flavors. 
(Parking is not always great, but you can almost always find something a few blocks away...it's worth the walk...you'll need it anyway.)
You will love this place. That's all.
author: Natasha T.

description:
Wonderful fresh baked goods!!

I'm a big fan of Arizmendi! I had heard great things about it from friends before and was definitely very pleased when I finally got to stop by to sample some baked goodness myself!

Mushroom, Red Onion, Asiago, Garlic, Oil, Parsley & Parmesan Pizza - Very good thin crust vegetarian pizza. I would definitely return for this and any of their baked goods : )'

Kookie Brittle - Really crisp, crunchy cookie chock-full of yummy chocolate chips and almonds. I LOVED IT! But, I think I will love anything and everything from this bakery

Their breads and pastries also looked fantastic so I anticipate many future trips to Arizmendi for my baked good fix : )
author: Lisa M.

description:
Finally got to try their foccacia bread, this one had grilled onions on them, it was super tasty! 
The cornmeal crust made it extra specially good!
I need to come back!
author: Jade B.

description: A friend and I were running errands and stopped by for lunch. We had pizza with roasted sweet potato, roasted garlic, sage oil, parmesan and parsley on it. It was SO good! I especially loved the thin, sourdough crust. The place is pretty small but cozy, and overall is a great place to grab a quick bite to eat =)
author: Jenn C.

description: I came here on a Monday evening and they were out of pizza which was disappointing. My boyfriend and I split a pecan roll, which was good. I wish they had asked if we wanted the pecan roll heated up, it would have been much better that way. Service was fast and pleasant!
author: Dar E.

description:
Ok i dunno why but everytime I try their pastries I always feel like they are kind of bland and not sweet or moist enough. I am trying really hard to LOVE it here but I just don't... To sum up what I've had so far

Chocolate chip cookie: BEST COOKIE EVER!!
Cherry and strawberry scone: Ok but kind of bland. Good crumbliness and moistness but Wish they added more sugar to it.
Cheese sourdough bread: Good!
Pecan Roll: a bit drier than I would expect and not sticky and gooey enough.
Apple strawberry coffee cake: nice and moist but a bit bland
Mushroom with the ginger vinegarette pizza: DELISH!!!!
Focaccia with potato, tomato thing: DELISH altho a bit chewy
Focaccia with pesto: kind of oily and bland and a bit chewy
Brioche Knot: SO DELICIOUS and soft and buttery with yummy raisins.
Mint Chocolate Chip Cookie: NOT GOOD. it had a weird taste to it and the mint taste wuz not very strong.
Pizza with Goat cheese, green peppers, mushrooms, etc.: Delicious! Loved the little bits of goat cheese and the sourdough crust.
Apple and Blueberry scone: yummy!

Seems they do a better job on their savory items. things here r hit or miss or ok
author: Em F.

description:
Arizmendi is like Cheeseboard's bastard child (or perhaps fraternal evil twin). They're essentially the same, but there's just something about Cheeseboard that Arizmendi lacks. 

Arizmendi is smaller, for one. It doesn't have the extensive cheese counter and it doesn't sell the reduced price end pieces of cheese to have with baguette in the morning.

They have a vast selection of vegan scones, cookies, etc. but they dont' carry certain of my favorites. They don't have the Hobrots (the cheese onion curry bread that's the most amazing thing) and their pecan rolls were on the thinner, harder side instead of soft. HOWEVER, they did have the most amazing pear ginger cranberry scone ever, which had  hunks of fresh pear, candied ginger and dried cranberries. Dear god that scone totally blew all our minds while sitting watching the fish at the academy.

Overall, they're a good bakery (more expensive, but understandable given higher rent). I like the co-operative spirit, but i feel it's still better orchestrated as Cheeseboard...
author: Stephanie H.

description: They seriously need to make a perfume of fresh baked bread....it simply attracts people...now what's sexier than that?...and, if i could choose the most perfect scent of fresh baked bread it would come from Arizmendi Bakery...right when you walk in, your intoxicated with such wonderful, aromas....the people are super sweet and the coffee even better...but like everyone said, nothing compares to their pizza.  Made daily with the freshest ingredients...It can get a little cramped in there...but who cares...anyone's overpowering cologne is highly masked with the sweetness of carbohydrates in the air...gotta love it!
author: Melanie S.

description:
I have lived in the sunset area all my life and did not discover this place until two months ago. how is that possible?! 

Anywho, just to repeat what other yelpers have said, this place is really something. I love their pizza and how they change it daily so that you always have something to try. I believe the first one i tried had a ginger sesame sauce on it or something close to that. it was unbelievably delicious. I wish i had ordered a lite-baked one for myself to take home. I also had one of their bread sticks which i have been trying to recreate for two months now but i just can't seem to get it to taste the same. The crunchy cheesy greasy stick is just what I want when i need a pick me up. Unfortunately, they go fast, so get a lot, and get them early

I have also had the opportunity to try their cheese roll, blueberry corn muffin, and pecan roll.

Cheese roll: i feel like it would have tasted better if it was warmed up.
Blueberry corn muffin: delicious cold or hot. but doesn't taste very good the next morning.
Pecan roll: too sweet but i never really enjoyed sweet stuff anyways.
author: Minerva l.

description:
I LOVE this place. Best pizza ever. If  you're in the mood for something a little esoteric it's fabulous, and not overly expensive either. The last pizza I had here was black olives, goat cheese, sweet onions and balsamic vinegar. It was perfect. 

Next time I'm thinking of having friends over but I don't want to cook (which happens often enough) I'll just order a half-baked pizza and heat it up at home. 

Come here if you want to grab something to go for lunch or take out for home, but there's not a ton of space so I don't recommend eating in. Also it's not a bad idea to pre-order your pizza too.  

Also, their pastries are pretty amazing too.
author: Ash S.

description:
Nothing like the promise of homemade shortbread shaped like poptarts, sticky pecan buns, and cheesy artisan bread to power me through a jog to Arizmendi's.  

This co-op bakery is a neighborhood favorite and a wonderful incentive to pretend-exercise. Go on, just take a brisk stroll around GGP (just a few blocks away), work up a small sweat, and reward yourself with mouth-watering pizza by the slice, crunchy 2-feet long breadsticks, and a slice of salted caramel chocolate cake. 

Then, stay away for a few days, dust off your old bike and make a cardio-pumping trek back for a nice 10% discount.  (Bicyclists get that extra boost--I like to think for reasons similar to my own).

Burn a few calories and reward yourself! Life is way too short for crazy diet shenanigans.
author: Daisy T.

description:
I've actually never bought anything from this particular location.  I've been going to their Oakland store off and on for a while.  If things are as good here, then ...

Their pizzas are just awesome!  Grab a slice, even pick up a whole par-baked one so you can finish baking it at home and get it while it's pipping hot.  They usually have a couple of flavors per day.  You can't order different toppings on it like a regular pizza joint, but their ingredients are always fresh and yummy.

Scones are great.  It has that moist, flaky, biscuit-y, buttery texture.  Cookies are yummy.  Ummm ... ginger molasas (I think) ...

I need to get off work earlier so I can come here.
author: Winnie C.

description: Everybody raves about this place, but I personally wasn't impressed. I had a blueberry muffin, and it was okay. A bit stale and not moist in the least, but okay. Always a huge line because everyone loves this place, I bet their pizza is fantastic. I may have just came on an off-day. I know their breads are highly recommended, and the shop has won crazy awards.
author: Emily H.

description: best bakery in town. they don't have things like donuts. this is a true bakery: home made scones & muffins and their pizza is unique and outstanding. 2nd location in Berkeley
author: Hyla S.

description:
The Cheese Board is closed on Sunday, so we decided to head to Arizmendi Bakery in Inner Sunset to get our pizza fix and then take a relaxing walk in Golden Gate Park.  We picked up:

1. Pecan Roll (good, but still not as good as CB).
2. 1/2 mushroom, spinach, pesto pizza - they warmed it up for us (see comment for 1).
3. 2 breadsticks to take home and eat with my homemade veggie soup (will eat later tonight).

Service: As nice as can be.
Ambience: Homey.

In general, I think people in the neighborhood come to Arizmendi's as much for the baked goods as for the community feeling you get as you sit and enjoy your food.  I left feeling happy.  L'Shanah Tovah.
author: Burrito M.

description: My first purchase was just so-so (I forget what it was), but since then everything has been yummy. My only disappointment is that they don't put olive oil on the focaccia. I also wish they were open seven days a week.
author: Claire K.

description: I don't really know what the hoopla is about, but this is a neighbor-y local kind of place. I like their pizza and foccacia, but little else. To me, at least, many of the baked goods are a bit too chewy for what I prefer. The scones are really crumbly, too.Still, it is obvious that they use the best and freshest ingredients. The seating area is small and always seems crowded with strollers and regulars standing around holding cups of coffee--I always fear that someone might spill hot coffee on another's infant, but that is just me. I usually go in when I am in a bit of a rush, so I find the scene a little annoying. I don't find the staff that friendly. I really like their soy lattes, though.
author: 和子

description: the scones here really are good, as 2 of my friends say. I got the currant one. It wasn't dry and it had good crunch on the outside. I love that! I wanna try the blueberry coffee cake next time. Nice find in the 'hood and friendly service.
author: Emm C.

description:
One of my favorite places.  I'm here 2-3 times a week in the morning.  The usual is the Cherry Corn Scone and an Americano.  Pecan rolls, Brioche and short bread cookies are great.  Afraid to try the cakes!!!!  Too many calories!!!

They make great pizzas!  A different pizza each day after 11:30am (veggie).  I haven't have a bad one yet!!!  

Close on Mondays : (
author: Ray Y.

description:
I went for the pizza and will be back to try baked goods such as the corn cherry scone and the amazing looking foccacia. 

My two pizza slice were artichoke/garlic/spinach (the only variety offered at the time) and took 8 minutes to warm. The crispy, non-burnt crust was well worth the wait, as were the chunky pieces of artichoke heart.

The counter staff were very friendly despite being less than an hour from closing and having a line almost out of the front door.

I will absolutely return to try other variations of the scrumptious pizza and, of course, their renowned baked goodness.
author: Seth S.

description:
Ohhh cheese roll...why must you taunt me so. I can't go in this place without grabbing 3 or 8. And if there still warm outta the oven. You feel like SF PD will give you a ticket for not at least getting one.. you gotta do it. The pizza is the shizznet. gourmet and healthy for you in an olive-oil, Italian bike sorta way (you know.. you feel healthy but pay the the price in the end... confused by that?... me too)
ANYWAY try the english mufffins too. they look like your average muff but when you make one later your wish you woulda grabbed a bag full.

The cool thing about this place is that its down to earth and not full of itself despite its long lines and popularity. Arizmendi reminds me of one of those hip bakeries frequented by Yuppies, who then become DINKS and then transform into DIWKs (double income with kids) but wish they were empty nesters with a big nest egg. (confused?...me too).
author: Lindonesia S.

description:
The wolverine* rolls are vegan.  Hold the presses.  That shit tastes like it's made with cream, lard, mayonnaise, baby buttocks and all things magical and delicious but in reality, it's vegan!  IN YOUR FACE, BABY BUTTOCKS!

Also, vegan cookies, awesome english muffins, often times vegan scones, good coffee and a sassy staff that makes me smile with how fast they move people through and still manage to be delightfully kooky.  usually people who are delightfully kooky are like, really fucking slow. 

But my mostest favoritist thing is that the garbage can is labeled "land fill".  All garbage cans should be labeled that...it really makes you think about what you're doing.  like shit, this paper plate can be composted or this bottle has got to be recycled.  i know that life moves so fast and sometimes it's easier to throw that diet coke (tm.  also DELICIOUS I DON'T CARE WHAT ANYONE SAYS ABOUT CHEMICAL DEATH) can in the garbage than recycle it but if you really think about it, that shit is ending up in a land fill and that fucking sucks because the earth is already fucked and you're just making it worse, you selfish, lazy assholio.

*Speaking of Wolverine, has anyone else noticed that I look JUST like Hugh Jackman?  IRREFUTABLE PROOF: http://images.yelp.com/photo?id=6Yufljif6FaToN4kQ6fuiA&s=l

I sent his agent an email letting them know I'm available for stand in work at a very reasonable rate.  I could also do public appearances for him if he's like, really busy.  Like that movie Dave with Kevin Kline when he stands in for the jerkwad President and then actually becomes a better president than the jerkwad President and then the first lady falls in love with him and then, shit, I can't remember the end.  But that would be like me and Hugh Jackman.  Awesome.
author: Laura B.

description:
At a loss for a good way to describe the awesomeness of Arizmendi I sought guidance in pop music.  After searching far and wide - I felt that only Sir Huey Lewis was able to accurately describe my love for Arizmendi:

The power of Arizmendi is a curious thing
Make a one man weep, make another man sing
Change a hawk to a little white dove
More than a feeling thats the power of Arizmendhi

Tougher than diamonds, rich like cream
Stronger and harder than a bad girls dream
Make a bad one good make a wrong one right
Power of Arizmendi that keeps you home at night

Chorus 1 :
You dont need money (actually you do, and it is cash only), dont take fame
Dont need no credit card to ride this train
Its strong and its sudden and its cruel sometimes
But it might just save your life
Thats the power of 'mendhi
Thats the power of 'mendhi

First time you feel it, it might make you sad
Next time you feel it it might make you mad
But youll be glad baby when youve found
Thats the power makes the world goround

Chorus 2 :
And it dont take money (well, it doesn's take credit cards anyhow), dont take fame
Dont need no credit card to ride this train
Its strong and its sudden it can be cruel sometimes
But it might just save your life

They say that all in love is fair
Yeah, but you dont care
But you know what to do
When it gets hold of you
And with a little help from above
You feel the power of 'mendhi
You feel the power of 'mendhi
Can you feel it ?
Hmmm

Chorus 3 :
It dont take money and it dont take fame
Dont need no credit card to ride this train
Tougher than diamonds and stronger than steel
You wont feel nothin till you feel
You feel the power, just the power of 'mendhi
Thats the power, thats the power of 'mendhi
You feel the power of 'mendhi
You feel the power of 'mendhi
Feel the power of love
author: Matthew H.

description:
Have you ever thought you didn't like something your entire life only to find out that you actually DO like it after all?  And you realize that all these years you have been missing out on its wonderfulness?

This is the scone. Thank you Arizmendi Bakery.  And thank you Amir A for offering me a bite of your scone even though I hate scones.  But I love cornbread and these scones taste like a delicious sweet corn bread delight of magical corney goodness and I want to crumble them into my mouth and build myself a scone castle in Sconesville and live happily ever after and also have a cornfield in my back yard with little possessed children hiding in it and whispering demonic things and  holding hatchets.*
  
Irish people don't know jack, and they should just stick to the whiskey and stop trying to bake, because my people ruined years and years of eating scones for me and I intend to take those years back, and also make my ass fatter because winter is coming and I'll need the insulation.  Scones ARE from Ireland, right?

*It's Halloween, just keeping things festive.
author: Starla D.

description: Fast, friendly service. Pizzas are always great and tasty. My favorite pizzas are the potato one and the ones with the different mushrooms. Parking is pretty difficult but plenty of public transportation options around.
author: T D.

description: My only regret is that I ordered only one thing from Arizmendi - the blueberry coffee cake - and now I'm about 600 miles away in Seattle with no plans yet to return. My husband got the pecan roll (like a cinnamon roll), and though I don't like pecans, MAN, all the sweet goodness made me almost want to trade pastries with him. I like the "grab it yourself" environment, although it's a little hard to navigate around other hungry people, but it sure beats waiting in line while the person in front of you takes 10 minutes to tell the employee what they want.
author: Melody I.

description: I love you Arizmendi's. I especially love getting your coffee cake & coffee on a Sunday morning before strolling through the Inner Sunset Farmers Market. Your focaccia makes me question my belief system. Your pizza makes me throw it out the window.
author: Allison C.

description:
I am sweating right now. Breathing at an insanely elevated rate too. My skin is crawling and my head screaming. My taste buds are crying out, "Bitch!! Drive your ass over to Arizmendi and feed me some of that pizza. Cheese rolls and sticky buns too." 
 
But there is a battle raging between those surly taste buds and my string bikini- newly purchased for my trip to Hawaii in less than 48 hours. OH GOD. Bikini. 48 hours.
 
Reason says to drink water and go to the gym. But the Ghost of Arizmendi Present is not having it. How can I deny myself the Baked Goods of the Gods after I've so foolishly sampled it's nectar? Answer: I can't. So to Arizmendi it is. Besides, Polynesians like their women curvy. Right?

RIGHT?!
author: Britt W.

description: Probably my favorite bakery in all of SF! I can't really walk by without getting a roll.
author: Anu K.

description: We were coming back from Ocean Beach and stopped here on the way home. I wanted to try everything it looked so good. We got the strawberry coffee cake and some cheese bread. SO good. I wish I lived closer to here.
author: Amy N.

description:
A few bites of the scones from of this place will make you scoff at the concept of any 'low carb' diet..... as if.... shaw.....

Their scones are amazing... their pizza (which *does* sell out) is an institution, and they could probably do a business just with their pizza alone. Their menu changes regularly so be prepared for a tasty surprise! They have Challah for the holidays, too! 

They have a tiny little area where you can sit and eat, which is busy during the lunchour- it would be nice if they had a larger area to sit. 

Half-baked pizzas are available 'to go' if you're looking for a fast dinner option!!
author: M'ia K.

description:
I've searched all over San Francisco for the best pizza by the slice, and had started to get discouraged until I discovered the pizza at Arizmendi. It is, to put it bluntly, Pizza of the Gods. And it's cheaper than some of the less divine pizza-by-the-slice shops around town.

In addition to the most awesome and creative pizza, this place is filled with appetizing aromas as soon as you walk in the door. It's a little rushed, because their are so many people coming in to get the great baked goods, and there's not much of a seating area - but I cannot count off any stars for that because this place is so good it wouldn't matter if they had seating or not. I would love for the delicious and rejuvenating energy of this place to multiply throughout the world. We would certainly have world peace!
author: Kent W.

description:
It's only fair for me to review this spot since I was there twice in two days.  I would have happily gone 18 times in two days, but it's a bit of a trek.
The focaccia is amazing and out of this world, if a little greasy and messy and ridiculously corn mealed on the bottom.  They had a mushroom pizza with sesame oil and some other stupid delicious stuff and wow.  I'm in love.  I just don't even know what else to say.  If you want to win me over, bring me Arizmendi.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Not everything from here is great. The wolverine is actually kind of vile. But their corn cherry scones, and corn blueberry muffins, and challah rolls are delicious

Now, let's consider their bialy. I give them major credit for carrying these, as you don't find them much in the bay area. And theirs is pretty traditional with onion and poppy seeds. It;s pretty tasty and makes a fantastic snack after you've walked clear on up from Bayshore and Sunnydale. Grab one, walk up the block and a half, and eat it in the park. YUM.
author: neil c.

description:
Honestly, I'd give the place 4 stars except they donate their baked goodies to the school I work for so I have to give them mad props for that!  5 stars it is!

Good cheese rolls [the starchy bread kind of rolls, not the pastry kind of roll], good pizza, and yummy selection of veggie breads.  Not to forget the scones, muffins, and other breakfast pastries.  

Everything is pretty damn good, highly recommended.  

Plus it's a co-op and a good Bay Area-er supports their co-ops.
author: Kat R.

description:
Small, employee-owned cooperative.  Very nice, polite, customer-oriented staff -- even when business is brisk. They're intent on getting your return business. Help and serve yourself to the breads, pastries, pizza.  Nice places to sit inside and out. 

Great for an eat-and-run: olive focaccia (only $1.50) and a cup.

Coffee's decent (but the refill price at 25 cents less than the first cup seems high) and is probably Fair Trade coffee.

The "pizza slices" are great.

9th and Irving so take the N Judah. Many nearby businesses and restaurants. GG Park's a block away.
author: Robert F.

description:
Um yeah, hi. I'm in the Inner Sunset right now and I can't believe how many delicious treasures this little neighborhood holds.

Just so you know, when coming to Arizmendi Bakery, it's gonna be busy. After you get over the initial hustle and bustle of this tiny little store your eyes will open up to a tasty assortment of the most delicious pastries your lips will ever touch in life.

Today, I grabbed an apple blueberry coffee cake and I thought it was just divine... a dream really. Totally worth the three bucks I spent on it.

The friendly man behind the counter served up a smile with my change and I thought that was a nice touch in a world full of unfriendly service and horrible mean people.

I heart this place.
author: Richard T.

description:
Apparently I've been living under a rock because I've never even heard of Arizmendi until recently.  But on Sunday, two people recommended it to me - one of them Yelper Shal J - so of course I took that as a sign from the gods and headed over to the Inner Sunset at the earliest opportunity.  

The mushroom focaccia that I bought to eat for lunch was fine.  I think that my lack of enthusiasm for it was more of a personal thing...I shouldn't eat focaccia anymore because most of the time I'd really just rather be eating pizza (I think I got there too early for pizza).  But the cherry/chocolate scone that I had for breakfast - oh, SO good!  Really, really yummy.  So fresh and crunchy - I like my scones very crunchy.  I was literally sad when I finished it and there was no more.

Next time I go back I'm going to try their pizza.  And another scone.

Update: 3/28/07 - You people have created a monster.  I found myself back there again today.  I was in the neighborhood (uh, sort of...I was visiting my sister in the Richmond, took a little detour on the way back home).  I tried the pizza and had an immediate flashback to Cheese Board last week: same one-kind-of-pizza-only deal, same delicious thin crust.  The only thing that marred the pizza for me was that it had sliced tomatos** on it.  But otherwise, it was really good.

**My tomato paradox: tomato sauce = Good!; finely chopped tomatos like on Zachary's pizza = Yum!; sliced tomatos, or tomatoes uncooked and in any way resembling their natural form: Yuck, gross, get it off my food!
author: DD B.

description:
This place is great. Its nice to go for a walk down Irving knowing that you will eventually end up here. The place smells really good and their daily pizzas are pretty yummy. The scones are a recommend. You cant go wrong with a nice clean, friendly, comfortable place to go for breakfast, lunch or anytime you have free time in the afternoon.

A+++ Recommend
author: David L.

description: Five stars for the pecan roll! Hory shit.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Arizmendi is a cooperative all right - they are cooperating with my mouth to make my ass bigger.

And it is all Yelp's fault, Yelp and you Yelpers jabbering on about how good this bread is, how yummy that pizza, cookie, brioche, scone - until finally I broke down and simply had to try it.  And now I sit here, glazed and dazed, my carbo addiction raging. Oh Yelp, I thought you were my friend, how could you?

PS: I also picked up some of the coffee beans they have and, oh momma, that brew will put hair on your chest.
author: GIR ..

description:
I am trying so hard to find a criticism of Arizmendi, and the best I can come up with is that they are not open 24/7 because I crave them all the time.  Being open Mondays and every day until nine or ten would be a good start.

The sourdough is the best I have ever had and inexpensive, the other bready delights are good too (especially brioche knots, scones, bread sticks, foccacia, foccacia with stuff on it that I think of as pizza, pizza, and whole wheat city bread with all the lovely little licoricey tasting things on top).

The staff is always really sweet natured, diligent and willing to accommodate.  The also make killer pizza.  One a day can be challenging, but at the same time I like having the less important decisions made for me.  If only Arizmendi could pick out my socks for me in the morning.
author: Quinn S.

description:
I had no idea that it was possible to get a slice of pizza in the Bay Area for less than $2.50. Thank you, Arizmendi Bakery.

And not just any pizza, gourmet pizza with all sorts of interesting toppings.

The crust was a bit lacking, as was the overall fillingness, but the creativity of ingredients more than made up for it.

Definitely would like to go back here and try some other creations.
author: Mark A.

description:
Why I feel the need to review a third Arizmendi is beyond me, except, well, it's (gulp) 9:30 at work, I still have something to finish, we ate the last of our frozen, half-baked, quartered, pull-out-at-will-and-bake-in-the-toaster-oven Arizmendi pizzas last night (oh so delicious), and I know when I get home tonight I'll have nothing to eat that's as easy and delicious, so that got me thinking about Arizmendi's, and how I mostly go to the Lakeshore Arizmendi's, but I like the one here too.  Not the one in Emeryville quite so much.

As I've said in my review of the Lakeshore Arizmendi's, the crust is amazing, and the toppings sublime.  I could never come up with the combinations.  Last night's had red cabbage and walnuts, and some amazing cheese, and it survived the freezer well (just as advertised).   Great, great product.  I'd invest.  If it weren't a cooperative hostile to concepts like investors.  It's one of my favorite (and frequent) meals.
author: Laurel B.

description: Damn you for making an amazing Brioche Twist...so chewy and gooey...equals to about an hour of redemption at the gym tonight...
author: Mimi T.

description:
I am in sheer lust with Arizmendi. There is no cure..so I must accept my fate and stuff my face with their amazing delectable delights. 

Their Corn Cherry Scones? Imagine amazing super cornbread..smear some honey lime jalapeo butter on that sucker and prepare to sink into a realm of extacy. Hell all of their scones are incredible. I once had an apple blackberry scone with lemon glaze that nearly made my eyes roll back in my head. According to my girlfriend their chocolate chip cookies are like really good natural Pepperidge Farm cookies - all I know is that they are pretty dang tasty..not chewy..not cakey..but still very good. 

Now lets talk some serious shop here...the pizza? Is the pizza really all that? Hell yeah it is. The crust is heavenly, the cheese fantastic, the toppings...((drool)). The only thing that can make me blue is a horrible craving for a delicious pizza topped with some of that rockin cilantro pesto..or sesame ginger dressing..and having to wait for it to come back into rotation...and at two dollars a slice - they totally win.

Cash or local check only. Go to their site to check out the goodies of the day.

UPDATE* - Please do yourself a favor and grab a Pecan Bun...oh..my..((passes out))
author: Natalie G.

description:
Last week I dropped by this place, had their focaccia and was sold.  This place rocks!  Ya just gotta love freshly baked bread.

If you asked me last week, I would have given this place a 5.  I went there this morning though and had a cheese roll and a cheese scone (I love cheese!).  Both were less than satisfying.  The cheese roll was reasonably good, but after last week's focaccia, I was slightly disappointed.  It was just too crisp and dry around the edges, and combined with the slight saltiness, it left me with a parched throat.  Perhaps I'm just not used to salty bread, but yeah, I wasn't thrilled, although the cheese sure was good.  The cheese scone...I took one bite and was done.  I was pretty full from the cheese roll, and with the cheese scone less than appetizing I was just done.

This review probably makes it sound like I dislike the place, but when I think of that focaccia I had the week earlier, I feel guilty for not giving this place 5 stars.  I'll come back again, hopefully to try the pizza out.  I'm sure that Arizmendi will finagle 5 stars out of me after I come enough times.
author: William C.

description: I love this place, nothing like fresh baked goods! Pizza was yummy as was everything else no complaints here!
author: Roger P.

description:
This is my go-to spot for pizza and scones. They have the BEST scones I have ever had in my life, and I've been around the tea house block so to speak so I've tried several scones. The fruit inside the scones is actually moist and the scone is doughy yet crumbly, rather than dry and tasteless like the average scone. You don't need to slather Devonshire cream all over the scone to give it some oomph like you need to at most tea houses, and you can eat the scones at Arizmendi without desperately needing a glass of water afterwards like the effect the typical scone may produce. 
 The vegetarian pizza options change daily and they are always amazing with vegetables that taste fresh, the perfect amount of cheese so as to be present and well incorporated with the rest of the pizza, yet not overwhelming. And the crust is the perfect mixture of crispy and chewy. 
When it comes to baked goods, Arizmendi knows what's up.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
OMFG!

How could I have passed by this gem all these times?  I'm totally kicking myself right now - or maybe not, the last thing my lard booty needs is more food to be addicted to.

On a whim, we decided to pop in here for lunch.  Fresh slice of the day served up piping hot for me, please!  Today's pizza, arugla, olive, goat cheese and olive oil...yeah, it was a little slice of heaven.  The crust was amazing!  Thin crust that had the perfect consistancy - it almost tasted like there was a hint of sourdough - man I love sourdough!!

Because we were feeling gluttonous, we decided to grab a few things to take home.  The mozzarella foccacia, a cheese roll and a chocolate chip cookie.  

Yeah, I'm so going back!  

I was close to giving them 4 stars because of the lack of dining space, but I decided not to be so petty.  The quality and sheer addictability (I know, it's not even a word!) of their baked goods makes it worth 5 stars!!
author: Christy L.

description:
Thank you so much, Arizmendi, for your nice strong UNSWEETENED Chai: The capper to the delicious baked goods.
:-)
author: Rita F.

description: had a slice of the Shiitake, portabello and button mushrooms, sesame-ginger-garlic vinaigrette pizza and it was DELiSH!!! i will be back to try another type of slice soon (especially since they have it posted online a month in advance)  i got a pecan roll to go and it was melt in your mouth AMAZiNG and worth every calorie filled bite! SOOOOO GOOOD!  we also got a Chocolate-Cherry Sourdough loaf that i cant wait to try later today :) the service was fast and friendly, i wish i worked at this awesome bakery. i am stoked to go back here soon :)
author: Elise B.

description: You're gonna want to get their chocolate cake with salted caramel frosting. One or two slices will do, but you should probably go ahead and get a whole cake, just to be on the safe side. Trust me, after that, all other cakes will pale in comparison.
author: Matt D.

description:
The N-Judah stops kitty corner to my apartment.  When I walk out and see the train pass I don't fret a bit..I say to myself "Woo hoo!! Brioche Knot here I come!" 

So I walk past the nasty ass Burger King and into Arizmendi.  It always smells so good and I always giggle because I heard on the radio that the top smells that men are attracted to are vanilla (AKA "Eau de Stripper"), butter popcorn (huh?) and baked goods (makes me wanna bake...ah yeah.)  So I wonder if it's true, does baked goods='Hey mama, how you doin'?

So each time I get the Brioche Knot....I love the Brioche Knot but I hate raisins. So I pick them out.  Each and everyone of those little wrinkly shits and when I do finally catch the Muni, I sit and eat my de-raisined Brioche Knot hoping that some fine specimen of a man will catch the aroma of baked goods wafting from my paper bag and say "Hey mama, how YOU doin'?  Or something a little more classy.....that is a pretty cheesy ass line.
author: Jay H.

description:
Oh, Arizmendi, how is it possible that your scones are this delicious?? The crisp sugar crunch of the top gives way to moist, tender innards-- not too sweet but exploding with flavor all the same. And what's that? A fresh, cool burst of blueberry? I've never had a scone like theirs before; they're so perfectly cooked that it causes other pastries to go green with envy. Try whatever their scone of the day is -- it's bound to be good, and is usually made with a fresh fruit that's in season. Their ever-present corn-cherry scones are also legendary for their crumbly buttery slightly crunchy delightfulness. Truly, Arizmendi has ruined me for all scones. I don't think it's possible to find a better one.

The chai that's served there is also some of the best around. "Sun-brewed honey-sweetened chai from Santa Cruz" is what it's billed as, and honestly I've never had better. It's worlds from the sugar syrup chai you get at Starbucks and even Peet's. Arizmendi's chai is slightly sweet, richly spicy, aromatic, complex, and strangely nostalgia-inducing, though you're not sure what for. It warms your belly and envelops you in comfort.

Not in the mood for something sweet? Their cheese rolls are a ridiculous food item--half chewy sourdough and half melted asiago, they'll fill you up and give you a jaw workout in the process. Their pizza is also amazing; this worker-owned co-op was trained by the famous North Berkeley standby, The Cheese Board.
author: Heather H.

description:
I love snickerdoodles and think they are the king of cookies and so I try to eat them everywhere I can. Unfortunately I did not love Arizmendi's version. Tasted just like a plain sugar cookie. Where was the cinnamon and crackly surface?! I'll stick to the cheese rolls and scones but I'm still fuming over the slight inflicted on my beloved.

The strawberry raspberry scone is one of the best baked goods I've had in a while! The chocolate thing is basically chocolate bread and the pecan roll is great reheated. Stick to the scones for a treat! I need to try that chocolate cake.
author: Nathalie L.

description:
Wow wow wow.

This is one of those things that makes you proud to live in San Francisco...even if it's a little more Berkeley than City for pricing (by pound not piece), attitude, informality, deadpan serious style.  But still.  I mean, a bewildering and changing selection of loaves, foccacia, bread sticks, cookies, short bread.  All cooked in the bakery cave behind the counter.  If it's flour based and it goes in the oven they make it.  And they have a soft spot for breads involving cheese.

If we had more places like this we might start getting an attitude like San Francisco is the center of the universe and we're better than everyone else....
author: Gil S.

description:
They have this nectarine coffee cake deal there that...I wouldn't steal for, like if I didn't have any money I wouldn't, like, knock off the nearest Walgreens for $ to buy it but, yeah, if they told me that the only way I could ever get one of those again would be if I used stolen money then...yeah, I'd steal for that shit. 

Other than that, all they have are great scones, pizza that is par for the San Francisco course (that is, eat your heart out New York-delicious), fantastic little cheese- and/or tomato-bread-rolly things, and totally delicious cookies and brownies. Basically, it's the kind of place that if it were in your neighborhood you'd be a) really thankful for and b) a little heavier than you might normally be. It is and I am x 2.
author: T U.

description:
I lived right around the corner from here for two years, and this was by far my mostly frequently visited neighborhood spot.

It gets pretty packed in the mornings... and at least when I lived there, they were closed on Mondays. 

Literally everything is delicious! 

One tip: you can get pizza by the slice, or get a whole pie in the afternoons, but I wouldn't overlook the focaccia pizza squares (artichoke heart, roasted red onion, and feta cheese are the best) they have out in the cases... they are to die for. 

Go here. Right. Now. No really, get on the N. You'll be hooked too.
author: Christina T.

description:
I hope Arizmendi has an obese Italian baker who wears a chef's hat and sports a badass moustache because I want to make love to him on a floured counter in the kitchen.

No, not really my style. I'm more of a slip and slide kinda girl. But whoever is cookin up those delicious pasteries, just know I'll jump your bones for a cheese roll.
author: Jen Y.

description:
Well being that I am the 142nd reviewer of this bakery speaks for itself, however let me spout off a bit.  I love this place, not only do they offer yummy ever changing pizzas, they have homemade english muffins, foccacia with salty wholesome goodness on top.

Not to mention...the staff is very helpful and friendly.  Helps that they are owners.
author: Brye L.

description:
Spending the beautiful, warm afternoon strolling through the Botanical Garden, we worked up an appetite. I'd never been though I claim familiarity with the neighborhood. Of course, being the pastry snob she is, this bakery was on the top of her list of good eats. 

The strawberry rhubarb scone called to her. And I had to try one as well. As this was lunch and dinner combined into one, we opted for slices of the mushroom pizza. It was hot, crispy thin, and delicious. So much flavor in these small slices.

Always good to find another place to share pizza, especially when it's this great! And there's an additional location in Oakland?! I'm amazed that I didn't know this. 

Glad I saved the scone to enjoy later.
author: Dave B.

description: flavorful guilt-free pizza, what more can a girl ask for?
author: Jen C.

description:
For the little Berkeley-ite in all of us.  These guys are basically Bay Area Food Royalty, so any good foodie should wend their way here on a pilgrimage sometime, and if you actually live nearby...way to be.

Consider the light-baked pizzas here (you finish baking them at home): all vegetarian, and probably the best pizza in the city on every count--crust, cheese, fresh toppings.  And that's just one of their many talents--bread fans shouldn't miss Wednesday's cheddar corn loafs either.

For me, though, this place will always mean Christmas cookies.  Ridiculously expensive, yet so good, Christmas cookies.  After all, tis the season to spend more than your better judgement tells you.  Plus you can keep the tin and put your homemade cookies in there, then take them to parties and try to pass them off as Arizmendi (but good luck with that).
author: Wes M.

description:
i'm a little scared what my precious apricot oat cookie holds (the grease stain left of the paper bag can't be a good indication), but the place is delicious.  the cheese selection isn't huge but they have a really tasty peppercorn brie.  the baked goods are all tasty as well.

the pizza is probably a small draw back.  maybe because so many people compared it to cheeseboard pizza in berkeley, i tried it with the hopes that it would be as good.  i would die if a cheeseboard moved near my school.  but alas, it was tasty but just not as good.

**edit 12/4/07**

ok.  so as time went on, arizmendi has changed from a "once-a-week" place to a "every-morning ritual" place.  the cherry corn scone, chocolate things and brioche knots are amazing.  especially if you get there early enough and they're fresh!  i still think the pizza isn't as good and diverse as cheeseboard but they have a few highlights.  the artichoke heart pizza and the squash pizza are awesome.  

my friend and i meet here for our morning snacks but we've decided that, for the sake of our health, we'll limit our visits to twice a week.  except during finals of course, when the pastry limits are lifted!!!
author: Thom Y.

description:
I'm sorry if this review doesn't make sense but I've been awake for 48 hours in marathon yet fruitless hacking session trying to crack Yelp and make a way to give Arizmendi 10 stars or maybe 9 thumbs up. Alas, I failed and so a mere 5 stars it is. In stupid per-star fashion:

1) Delicious, nutritious food. Their food is fucking awesome and whole and delicious and good for you and delicious and a San Francisco classic and delicious. Quality foods made with love are no joke. The pizzas are creative and delicious. The breads are so so right. Cookies? Yum. And if that weren't enough, they carry some of the best local products around, like Cowgirl Creamery cheeses and Charles Chocolate.

2) The owners. The whole enterprise is worker-owned, and it shows in their attention to quality and attitudes toward work. "Owner wanted" signs, not "help wanted": proving that it's a positive, effective business model every day. They listen to rad tunes in there and usually have some witty comeradery banter going on. They know and care for their regular customers. 

To those in other reviews that have complained, I say try again, take an average. They're often really busy and trying to juggle counter service with baking, and in my extensive experience they are almost always friendly, kind, patient, and helpful. Honestly, I'm amazed none of them have ever jumped over the the counter to introduce the roller-pin to some of the people they get in there. You can bet your ass I'd have fallen down like that if I had to be in at 4 AM (4! AM!) to bake you your bread and then you bitched about me not taking credit cards or me not being psychic about what bread you put in that huge paper bag or because I'm not *thrilled* to tell you how to finish baking your pizza when the instructions are printed right there on the m-f'ing box.

3) Coffee. Soy special... *pant pant pant*. They serve a Fair Trade coffee, and for my money they're the best in the neighborhood, with the possible exception of the Beanery at Irving & 7th. Beats Fourbucks, beats Beanery 9th, beats Canvas, beats Tart to Tart.

4) Sustainable. Arizmendi works hard to make sure they create as little waste as possible. Most things are compostable, including their "plasticware". What little isn't goes in their waste bin, thought-provokingly labeled "land fill". They regularly win awards for how well they recycle & compost, so they clearly have something to teach us.

5) Community oriented. They make regular donations to the food bank of their unsold goods. They also give sweet discounts: seniors, bicyclists, members of other co-ops. Was a time that MUNI FastPass counted, but think that's been lifted. Anyway, they're all owners, right, so that's money out of each of their pockets. That's commitment to the community. 

Like I said before, they care about their regular customers, which makes the neighborhood feel more like a community and less just the immediate area. A little bit of that goes a long way, and they do more than a little.

7) Make loaves, not war.

8) The two chicks in their underwear, who, at 1 AM one night, pulled up in a Mercedes sedan, frenziedly pitched a gang of bread out of Arizmendi's compost bins into its trunk, and then sped off like the heat was on.

9) Arizmendi's pumpkin cheesecake = everything that pumpkin pie always wanted to be, but never, ever, ever was.

10) Chaynge? Chaynge? Chaynge?

Go there early and often.
author: Striddy B.

description:
Pizza.  English muffins.  Corn-cherry scones.  Cheese rolls.  Shortbread.  Chocolate cake.

It's all tasty and amazing.  They make me wish carbs were irrelevant and money were no object.  When they were on my daily commute, life was gooooood.

The biggest down-side to Arizmendi--closed on Mondays.
author: Lea G.

description:
The baguette here is the best in SF -- and the scones are addictive!! Great place to stop, great prices, independent local business and not a chain..what more could you want. 

The Pizza is excellent.  It's not new york or chicago etc style pizza, but it's not trying to be -- it's california-style fusion pizza on great dough.  Formerly a New Yorker, most SF pizza fails to satisfy but this is a nice treat because it's different.
author: Shamus S.

description:
Love the pecan roll - moist, lots of pecans, not too sweet (but flavorful), and the right amount of glaze. Not too enthused about their cookies or tomato/olive focaccia (not that it was bad - just something I wouldn't crave for). Also, the thin-crusted, basil/tomato/artichoke pizza is delicious! Most, if not all of their daily special pizzas are amazing! 


Their chocolate cake with salted caramel frosting is also yummy - (but check the color of the frosting - if there's some discoloration - do not buy it! It's not fresh, and blatantly - inedible. Arizmendi should really chuck it otherwise) 

Ultimately, I am sooo thankful that this bakery is within the vicinity of my workplace...this makes the sunset district so much better.
author: Audrey L.

description: One of my absolute favorite spots in SF. Delicious baked goods. You have to try the ricciarelli cookie - that's the Italian, almond one. So delicious! Also they just added more benches outside and extended their hours. Yay! Only bummer: they only take cash so make sure you have some on you.
author: Kay S.

description:
sightly different than sister/cousin Cheeseboard Pizza in Berkeley - I'd say the crust is a bit more sour/chewy. Also has way more baked goods and stuff besides pizza!

Other than that, pretty much the same deal - cooperative that makes one kind of amazing veggie pizza per day. A new adventure every time you go...
author: S V.

description:
This place is what makes Sundays the best day ever.
Their Mocha is the best one i have ever had.
The cookies, obviously the pizza- makes my mouth water just thinking about it. The cheese roll is also amazing.
author: Elif U.

description:
I think it is the best bakery in SF.  If not for the fine fine city bread, for the atmosphere of joy... and hapiness that it brings to me and my sunset community. 

sunday mornings never felt better.

wake up... coffee... bring some champagne before stopping in at the bakery.. head to golden gate park for muffins and mimosas?

I feel bad for living so well here.  Cheaply... but well.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
Phenomenal pastries, breads and pizzas.  The brioche knots and chocolate things are to die for.  I still remember so vividly the special plum scone with the huge chunks of plum.  And the coffee (Equator) is fantastic.  

During really busy times when the line is long, the etiquette can be a bit confusing/interesting.  Do you get in line first and pick up pastry on the way to the counter?  Or pick up pastry first and then head to back of the line?  People, including myself, do different things at different times.  Not a worry as It always seems to work itself out.
author: Leon R.

description:
The scones here are DIVINE. Absolutely scrumptious. Ridiculously good.

Before Arizmendi, I thought scones were SUPPOSED to be dry, dense & tasteless - but had them on occasion anyway as an alternative to greasy muffins and put them on my perennial maybe-they'll-be-better-this-time-food list.

Scones from Arizmendi can kick any muffin's ASS any day. Lightly crispy on the outside; perfectly fluffy & moist on the inside. Choke full of goodies like apple chunks, currants and cherries. All the different varieties are good, but the corn-cherry number is out of control. 

The bakery is a co-op, manifested in its communal vibe & down-to-earth staff . You just feel good when you come here.

All their other offerings are delectable as well. I'm just crazy about their scones.
author: Kathy Y.

description:
I steer clear of bakeries since muffins, scones, and breads seem like snooze filler to me. But I'm sure I've found the BEST joint for fresh pizzas in SF.
