Papa Murphy's and Papa John's would not last in SF since Arizmendi would blow both socks off with it's own version of "Take and Bake." I picked up a marinated mushroom, garlic, red onion, and olive oil white pizza and popped it in the oven for 8 minutes.  This "whole" pizza was a reasonable $16 and could easily feed 3 people. Last night there wasn't a third person around so my pal Angela and I inhaled the entire pizza. 

Most pizza places these days subject one to sodium shock and I find having to resuscitate myself with a gallon of water after a few slices. Arizmendi, on the contrary, uses natural ingredients sans the yellow cheese and immense salt at other places, creating delicious pies.

Their pizza changes daily and menu available on their website. You can plan ahead your pizza bonanzas weeks in advance.
author: Jonny M.

description:
I seriously don't know why I don't come to this place more often. It's your one-stop shop for all your breakfast, lunch, or snack cravings. I went to Arizmendi's after my friend, Christine brought it up a few nights ago and I decided to pop in to see if everything's still as good as I remember.

Let me tell you, this place hasn't skipped a beat. From the moment you enter and get that waft of freshly baked goods, you wonder why you don't frequent the place more. Perhaps my favorites are the daily pizzas and mushroom/parsley foccacia. Today, the pizza special was spinach, olives, garlic oil, and feta cheese. Let me first say that I usually hate spinach and feta with a passion, but somehow Arizmendi's makes it work. Their pizzas aren't the norm most of you are accustomed to---more of a homemade style with thin crust, but they are definitely as good as advertised by my fellow Yelpers. My mouth is watering just thinking about it.

I have not yet tried all the baked goods this gem has to offer, but I'll get around to it. I have, however, tried the assortment of scones which are definitely fantastic with their lightly crusted exteriors, and soft moist interiors. For sure they're a nice change up from those Chinese "baos" I grew up with (BBQ Pork Buns, Cocktail Buns, Pineapple Buns). You know what I'm talkin about people.

The only thing bad thing about this place is there's almost always a line, but that's only because it's so damn good. Keep up the nice work, Arizmendi's!
author: jeff c.

description:
Arizmendi is my mendi!  Their baked goods rock my world.  Great tasting brioches, schones, pizza, muffins, & all fresh.  Also xlnt granola, better that most Rainbow granolas.  I have yet to try their bread, am sure it's top shelf, though.  Good organic coffee to pair with their offerings.  My favorite muffin is carrot corn, so good with butter & when it's warm out of the oven!
Keep in mind they're cash only, being a co-op.  But if you ride a bike to this marvelous establishment, they give you 10% off auto.  I like spots that offer bike discounts.
Hurray for Arizmendi!
author: Roland C.

description:
I am addicted to everything here. Particularly the hot, fresh challah that comes right out of the oven on Friday mornings and straight onto my stomach. I like to roll on it, and then when it's good and dirty, I stuff it down my gullet.

There is almost always a line here and not a lot of room to sit down, unless you are very small and greasy, which I am, but if you're not into tight spaces, plan to take your amazing bread or pastry or pizza to go. 

I love the people who run this place-- they are ALWAYS patient and friendly even when the place is packed like a madhouse ship of fools, and four-footeds are welcome!

OH, and if you ride a bike,  or a unicycle, or an underwater robot, tell them-- you get a 10% discount.

-Lola the otter (and sometimes ferret)
author: Lola B.

description: Yum! I'm not supposed to eat dairy products,but when I do this is the place I do it.The fococcia is amazing.So is the potatoes bread, baguette pieces and everything I've tried here.
author: Susan W.

description: Service was friendly, had a focaccia topped with carmelized onions, spinach, mozzarella, and pesto, which was pretty tasty.  Like to go back and try some other baked goods that looked very delectable.
author: Jon C.

description:
If this place someday decided to become a pizzeria, they'd be the best in California! Their dough is heavenly! OMG the best pizza dough on the planet! Their pizzas are mouth-watering which leaves me begging to try out a classic margherita made by them! (if anyone from Arizmendi - or the cheeseboard-- is reading this please please please take this into consideration!)

Their breadsticks are sooo good with whichever cheese you choose to try... (Humboldt Fog is my favorite!)

They get 10 stars because co-ops rock!
author: Maddy S.

description: This weekend I scooped up the apple and blackberry coffee cake for a bbq... was DEVOURED...so delicious.....
author: Julie F.

description: Great items. I love the pizza and the blue berry cornbread muffins. I would like them to carry more whole wheat/spelt items.
author: KellyMoi M.

description:
I've always wondered about this place. I see the lines and go is that place really that good? On my way home Friday there was about five to ten minutes until they closed and I saw they were still open so I walked there to see what they had.

There was bread, scones, muffins, and cookies. I looked around and tried to be quick since I know they were trying to close. 

I read the ingredients to see what was in there and I saw no raisins and went that's a winner for me. I saw the scones and went, I wonder how those will taste. I bought two strawberry blueberry scones. OH man! They were good!

They had some moisture and the texture was good. I'm glad I stopped by. 

I will be stopping by again hopefully soon for some more of these yummy scones.
author: Jen C.

description: Can I give it 5 hearts? The scones are great, the coffee is strong, and you get a 10% discount if you flash your muni pass! 5 stars for phenomenal baked goods, even if the cashiers are a bit snippy sometimes. I also recommend the shortbread. I would get off the muni and get back on to go to work because I wanted their baked goods so much on some mornings.
author: Netty L.

description:
One piece of their amazingly delicious coffee cake is about as big as my face. 

Talk about a tasty brunch.
author: Geoff W.

description:
Whenever we're in the mood for pizza, we try to get some here.

At breakfast today, we shared a cinnamon bun, a coffee crumb cake square, and a cheese-tomato foccacia round. I didn't expect them to taste as good as they did. 

If you want anything bread-related or baked fresh from an oven, Arizmendi is the place. A true neighborhood staple--this place kicks ass, really it does.

I need to get a scone on my next visit. Oh yeah, and the coffee at Beanery (http://www.yelp.com/biz/beanery-san-francisco) very closeby goes great w/ Arizmendi anything. It's always freshly roasted and doesn't sit around for long.
author: Kay N.

description:
I do not believe there is one baked good on offer at Arizmendi that I would not serve on my table.  We're particularly fond of the cornmeal-cherry scones, kookie brittle and any cookie and let us not forget the cheese buns.

This is a great little bakery where staff seem sincerely pleased to be a part of the team and it shows.  Well done!
author: Jay D.

description:
On Sunday morning you can have three great things here! Great cup of coffee (or bring it in from the Beanery), great knotted bun with raisins, great view of Marina post booty-call booty coming in to figure out which neighborhood they've had the misfortune of spending the night. 

They also have the most under-publicized flat crust pizza. Delish! Amazing baked goods. Generally a nice, mellow place to hang out before starting the day.
author: Johnny C.

description:
My girlfriend and I have planned entire weeks around the pizza schedule here. You can get a slice, a half or a whole pizza here, and you can even ask for a "lite bake" if you want to finish baking it at home. Last week we passed on manchego cheese in favor of triple mushrooms, so this week we went on Friday for their arugula, tomatoes, manchego cheese, garlic oil and parsley pizza.

Doesn't that ingredient list alone just make your mouth water?

This is coming from someone who will suck the marrow out of beef bones stewed in chicken blood. Or whatever it was that we ate on Thursday. I love their pizza so bad I almost want to go veg (at least Tuesdays through Sundays). Or maybe it's the thought that I possibly ate chicken blood stew earlier this week.

I wish they had a larger cheese selection, but the bakery is very small and understandably selective. I also wish that the half pizza we got yesterday was warmer and less soggy, as the pizza is usually served hot and toasty. These slight transgressions were made up for by the cheerful homeless man outside.

My co-worker asked me to bring her a ginger shortbread cookie from here, enticed by the thought of a ginger-based dessert. It was delicious. The flavor was so delicate that its lingering aftertaste surprised and pleased me. But then, everything sounds good now that I've brought up chicken blood.

A word on parking: I hear it's a bitch. But I used to live in North Beach, where parking is a VENGEFUL bitch. Take heart in the fact that someone, somewhere in this city is having a harder time parking than you are!
author: J P.

description: I was ecstatic when I saw the bakery so close to Howard's Cafe because it had been on my bookmark list for a while. I decided on a currant scone even though I am not much of a scone person, but it was delicious! You can tell how fresh their baked goods are and now that my BF moved closer to this part of Sunset, Irving will be my new go to spot and Arizmendi will not replace Copper Kettle for my baked goods =)!
author: Surge C.

description:
This bakery is outstanding. The pizza is terrific and baked good are always wonderful.

My favorite savories are the zampanos, the special pizza, and the focaccias. My favorite sweets are the cherry corn scone, the currant scone, the oat scone, and usually whatever fresh fruit pastry they have is wonderful. 

My only gripe is it's cash only. And for those who are confused- this is the exact same thing as the place on Lakeshore in Oakland. Same place, same stuff. I've never noticed a difference in taste or quality and I've been to both locations many times
author: Amanda C.

description:
I had a streak going recently, where I came here every morning for 10 days straight.  I was surprised that there was a different crew behind the counter every day and the sizes of the muffins and scones varied as well.  I think Wednesday was biggest (just kidding, sorta).

The point is, either there's cocaine in the food and coffee, or it's just that good.  I am going through Arizmendi-withdrawl because they decided to close between Xmas and New Year's.  Thanks guys.  I'm dizzy and shaking.

In my opinion, the coffee is actually the best part.  It has a hint of chocolate to it, and I'm not usually one to go off about crap like that.  I also love the bran muffins, oat scones, banana walnut muffins, and blueberry cornbread muffins.

Some people love the "pizza."  I think it's not pizza.  To each their own.

On weekends you're likely to see a mentally handicapped man panhandling outside.  I'm pretty sure he's not homeless, and you have to to give the guy credit--of all places in the neighborhood to panhandle, Arizmendi has the most foot-traffic AND the people most likely to give money to a panhandler.  How much would he get in front of Starbucks?
author: Jin D.

description:
G.K. Chesterton once said, 

'Do not enjoy yourself. Enjoy dances and theaters and joy-rides and champagne and oysters; enjoy jazz and cocktails and night-clubs if you can enjoy nothing better; enjoy bigamy and burglary and any crime in the calendar, in preference to the other alternative; but never learn to enjoy yourself.'   

Although I can't seem to avoid enjoying myself, I'm sure these are sagacious words; for whenever I come to this bakery, I look around at their rich treats--especially the pizza of the day--and I become a sinner.   The breads here are rich and dense (sometimes oily), and the pizzas are paradoxically high-end and production-line Cal-cuisine.  

4 stars because I like my breads light and/or flakey.
author: Nom D.

description:
I'm the antithesis of a bakery person. I don't like baked goods, I rarely nosh on cookies for the very reason that they usually all taste supremely processed. Plus, I'm not too hot on the thought of extra carbs. I'm wary of the baked goods *narrows eyes*.

On my last trip to SF this weekend, my girlfriend took us to Arizmendi because she swore on the awesomeness of the "chocolate things" (a pastry with chocolate chips inside). Chocolate things, however, were all sold out. I got a strawberry rhubarb scone and she made well with a brioche. The scones were out of this world. None of that generic processed taste, they use only organic ingredients. Very tasty. The brioche was fluffy and fresh. Each pastry costs about $2.50. The bakery also has an offering of focaccia breads and...CHALLAH! 

I have to say though, CASH ONLY IS NO BUENO! I went there twice over the weekend and on the last time, failed to scrap up enough change for a scone. Sad. 

Suffice to say that the Arizmendi might have coverted me to a bakery lover, but it will take another trip to convince me.
author: Alyce H.

description: I don't even like scones!!!!! Ever .. EVER! Arizmendi is DELISH!!! I can't get enough!! The fact that I work right by them is a death trap!!! love love love.
author: Rachael B.

description: Their savory cheese bread sticks are really fantastic. Nice and crusty with a good  chewy texture makes these a good reason to get more than one. The carrot and corn-blueberry muffins are almost the most perfect muffins I've had ever. Not too sweet and very moisted and wholesome. Nice and friendly service, a very welcoming place with organic baked goods and breads.
author: Wolfy W.

description:
I'm sad I no longer live near Arizmendi.

The good:
* The scones. This is their forte by a mile. The seasonal fruit scones rock. And you can't go wrong with the all-season Corn-Cherry scone or the Currant scone.
* The pizza. It's not your usual pizza, but it's damned tasty. My only gripe is that all the daily flavors kinda seem the same.
* The "Chocolate Thing" (that's what they call it!). Damn I love those chocolate things. If you take them home be sure to heat them up for a bit in the microwave or oven to get the chocolate to that yummy gooey state.
* The vegan mint-chocolate chip cookie. I'm not even vegan and I love this cookie.

The bad:
* Their breads. I prefer lighter breads, Arizmendi's breads are uber dense. If you're into that, great. I'm not.
* Their hours. They're not open on Mondays. This always bums me out :-(
* The shop is damned tiny. If seated, you'll be cramped. Be prepared to elbow your ways to the scone rack.

But really, order the scones and you won't go wrong. You'll also have a hard time eating any other bakery's scones in the future too...
author: David P.

description:
I'm so sad that I've been in San Francisco for over 3 years and haven't stopped by this place.  It makes me wonder...how many other gems there  are hiding in the city, especially among the outer avenues.   I mean, I only recently stumbled upon Peasant Pies a few blocks away and that was also a sweet find.  

I had 2 slices of the pizza of the day and yes, there's only one pizza option to choose from.  It was tomato sauce-less (as most, if not all of their slices are) , but it was fresh, hot, and fabulous.  Cheese, spinach, feta, olives, and some other good stuff.  I was also wowed by the freshness and flavor of the coffee cake and currant scone that I also picked up.  I'm definitely coming back soon to try some more of their pastries.  And did I mention it's a Co-Op?  I've decided that I officially love Co-ops.  How come there aren't more of them out there?  If you're in the East Bay, they have a second location under the same name and a sister restaurant that's apart of the same Co-op called Cheeseboard pizza.
author: LaSha G.

description: I love Cheeseboard, and Arizmendi is a good stand-in in San Francisco, but it's no Cheeseboard.  Because there's not the same sort of lines, the pizza is not always fresh or warm.  Also, I've been there a couple of times when they've run out, which is always sad.  However, the topping combinations are similar, and you can tell that the ingredients are top-notch.  Their breads are also very good, as well as the shortbread.  The people are super nice and helpful too, but it's also a problem that they close at 7, because that means I can't always get there before in time to get pizza when I'm craving it.
author: Pilan C.

description: Out of towner here from Florida.. this place is simply delicious! One of, if not the best bakeries I've ever been to! Plus it's a co-op which makes it even better. Go support this great place! Back home we don't have many places like these, if one were to ever pop up I know I'd be a regular customer daily. The locals around here need to appreciate the awesomeness they have!
author: Alex F.

description:
There's some addictive element in their chocolate tasties. I wake up in the morning craving for a Chocolate Thing. On my drive to work, I will park my car out front, risking getting a ticket, just to buy one.

My top three things to get:

1. Chocolate Thing (which is a tasty scone with chocolate chips)
2. Chocolate Fudge cake
3. Mint Chocolate Chip cookie

I agree with the other reviews about the bread/pizza/non-sweet things. They are hit-or-miss, or okay at best. However, the above three items are totally amazing.

It's a nice stop for a dessert or a morning scone to complement the coffee. I wouldn't go there for a regular meal (their pizza) or buy bread frequently (once in a while is okay).
author: Abid M.

description:
Get over it: Arizemendi is good, not great.

The majority of the 140-plus reviews have lauded the bakery, citing its co-op ownership, its pastries, and its coffee as the bar for which all pastries must live by. While it's a lofty measure, it's a standard stretched horribly awry. Inconsistency wrought an otherwise great bakery.

A cursory glance around the reviews indicates the cheese rolls as the number one item to sample. Hell, even Arizemendi agrees, too: the cheese roll sits firmly next to the door above all other pastries, encased in a cabinet double the size of its brethrens. The cheese rolls, without a doubt, is their bread-and-butter item.

Sadly, the cheese roll is an astounding..."eh"!

The roll's praise is unjustified: underneath the cheesy pastry, a tough, hard dough waits for unsuspecting teeth, to shatter and crush them with no remorse. The tough-as-nails dough will either (a) scrape the roof of your mouth, or (b) give your mouth a hell of a workout -- taebo for the jaw. And wait, there's more...the roll isn't even that cheesy. 

Another over-hyped aspect is their coffee. Brewed at god-knows-when, sitting for who-gives-a-crap, the coffee is totally lackluster in its flavor and aroma. Caffeine jolt? Forget about it! Pleasing taste? No way! Philz or blue bottle or even starbucks trumps Arizemendi by taste, by flavor, and, most importantly, by caffeine.

Wait, worse of all, they don't accept debit cards. The horror!

But not everything is overrated. The scones are butterly delicious. The onion roll peppered with sesame seeds is heavenly. And the pecan pastry is to die for.
author: Richard L.

description:
So I explained the bad blueberry corn muffin situation to the cashier and she gave me a free muffin and pecan roll.  No problem. 

I love this place.
author: Monica L.

description:
If God knew how to bake he would have stopped making so many ugly people and would be a co-op'd owner of Arizmendi.

I would buy a delicous pear and cranberry scone from him but I would not subscribe to his politics!



*Oh! and if you ride your bike there they give you a discount - pedal power!!!!!
author: scott w.

description:
I'm a conflicted person because honestly I'm not that crazy about my neighborhood, but I love living next door to such good eats. We really have some of the best food in the city here in the Inner Sunset, if only I didn't have homeless people setting up a drinking party in my driveway every day and threatening my life when I ask them to move, if only people stopped double parking and blocking the N-Judah, forcing the inevitable window busting "GTF out of my way" horn, if only.. 

Among the things I'll miss when I inevitably leave this neighborhood for less sullied pastures will be the Arizmendi Bakery. The baked goods here more than hold their own when compared to better known establishments such as Tartine. Everything they make here is delicious, and as a transplanted New Yorker I can honestly tell you I've never had a better bialy. Five star food made by five star people in a two star neighborhood.
author: Tal K.

description: Went here with my girlfriend today for an early lunch before class. All I can say is get here as early as you can, because this is definitely a busy place. We were lucky enough to get there right before the line got intense and boy were we glad. The Pizza of the day was absolutely fantastic. Light but very rich in flavor. We ordered a couple of the Focaccia breads and those were amazing. I recommend the roasted peppers and sun-dried tomatoes, but get there early because if you come at an odd hour all their stuff is cold. It doesn't change it from being amazing though! The coffee was absolutely fantastic too. Definitely going to go back their soon. Loved it!
author: Michael N.

description:
So I grew up in Berkeley, going with my mama to the Cheese Board loooong before they ever dreamed up the whole pizza thing, so I don't feel the need to expound the virtues of the hippie co-op with the amazing pizza and lines out the door, etc. In fact, I've never had Arizmendi's pizza. I'm sure it's the bomb. I'm giving this, my neighborhood bakery, 5 stars based on only three crucial elements: 

1) SOLID lattes (great espresso and they make good foam)
2) OUT OF THIS WORLD brioche
and 
3) CHEESE ROLLS that, on the right morning (and after the right night) can make a grown woman weep.  Okay, so I've never actually cried, but that's because I was too busy inhaling the cheese roll, and if you've ever tried simultaneously eating and crying you'll know it's really difficult and can actually give you a wicked case of the hiccups.
author: Madie S.

description:
They may be pinko-marxist-hippies, but you'd never be able to tell from their baked goods. 

Incredible bread, scones, and bialys.    

Everyone raves about their pizza but I'm unconvinced.  They have good flavors, but the texture isn't quite right -- like the oven wasn't hot enough or something.   

All in all, a great bakery with friendly staff, good products, and full of neighborhoodies.
author: Phil K.

description:
Taste the difference. Fresh baked breads are really yummy. 
It's a tight space here esp. when the place gets busy. 
I still prefer the Cheese Board in Berkeley but if you can't make it out to East Bay this isnt a bad option.
author: Lisa C.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco's Sunset District my entire life and I have to say, Arizmendi Bakery is my favorite by far.
love the cheezy bread sticks (if i can get there before they run out), all the scones are awesome, my favorite is the cherry corn scone. delicious. their gourmet pizza is fantastic too. perfect for starting the day, getting thru the day, and ending the day on a good note :)
author: Brian T.

description:
Real food that tastes great!  I could eat their oat scone or cornmeal cherry scone everyday... but then I guess my life would seem kinda boring.  I really could though...  Yummmmmmmmmm!  Thank you for existing.

Arizzzzmmmm... I still stumble on the name, but as soon as I do everyone chimes in with "ohhhh, yeah, I know exactly where you're talking about... so good...."
author: Becky S.

description:
Parking is a downer, but cheese bread and pizza ROCK!!!  

If you've ever been to Cheeseboard, this place is a close second.  It's like a surprise gift every time you go, because the pizza changes daily.  Oh goodness, the crispy thin crust, fresh ingredients, and drool-worthy toppings make me want to jam 5 slices in my mouth!
author: Jennifer H.

description: I've never had the pizza here, even though Arizmendi is well known for its pizza. I'm writing this review because this place makes the best scones ever. I didn't know what a scone was supposed to taste like until I had one from here. Dense, yet soft on the inside, full of flavor. Just amazing.
author: James L.

description:
Bring your muni pass and show it off. You'll get kudos and a discount off your purchase. 

The breads are nice and crusty - very heavy - just the way I like them. The coffee here is made a bit too strong for me.

My favorite is their pizza - purchase by slice or get by the half or whole pie to go. I just have to remember to do that more often for dinner. Everyday this pizza menu changes - SO yummy and creative!
author: Judy L.

description:
Got a pecan roll this morning and it was warm...It was so delicous that I will never head over there late morning to get one...they get a little harder and need to be warmed up then...not the same thing.

This is a perfect way to start off the day!
author: Benjamin T.

description: This review is based on my first visit here and will be updated as I make more visits to give a fuller review. I don't understand all the rave reviews about the pizza. The pizza was not so good. It was a bit dry, not very fresh and the flavors were there but they were a bit burnt. It was hard to see the listed ingredients on the slice. I prefer NY style pizza. This pizza just left me wondering when it was made. I've had pizza in southern Italy, NY, NJ, Texas, many other places in the US, Europe, and many spots in SF as well and this pizza didn't even come close to competing. Well there is no competing with southern Italy's pizza but that is the source so go try it and you will see. I bought a loaf of bread here also and its was a bit hard and not as fresh as I expected. I will return to this place to try the pastries, coffee and I'll give the pizza another chance and update this review to be fair.
author: Hugh M.

description: Food here is nothing special and not worth waiting in line. Sorry, I'm not a hipster wannabe person that lines up just cause others say this place is good while in reality the food is nothing special.
author: Max P.

description:
I love the pizza at this place, but it seems a little like the soup Nazi in there. The first time I went, I asked all the questions that you need to ask to take a pizza home and cook it. The lady helping me just seemed bothered by me. I could have very well caught her on the day that her cat went pee in her granola, so i can't judge them on that experience alone.

I have since gone back several times and I love this place. It's San Francisco pizza....Chicago has there's and so does New York...but this SF'S!!!!!
author: JR H.

description:
BEST VEGETARIAN PIZZA, EVER.   

And you can't really go wrong with anything else here either.
author: Shirley F.

description: I have a couple of favorites here that I purchase over and over again whenever I'm in the area.  I love the blueberry scones particularly when it's still warm from the oven - crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside and loaded with blueberries.  I love the brioche knot also with its light glaze on the soft bread and loaded with golden raisins.  On occasion I'll have a chocolate thing too.  Yes, it is loaded with chocolate.  Perhaps I'll decide to sample some of their other baked goods on future visits, but for now I'm happy just sticking to my favorites.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: I'm a huge fan of fresh baked bread, pastries & pizza, in fact those are the material possession's I will likely be put in the ground with. This place has an incredible selection & each day they bake a special pizza. Saturday after a hair cut (at sunset barber shop, which rocks the mike) I headed over to check out the special pizza of the day. Triple mushroom baby!! The crust is super fresh and crunchy, the cheese combo is great & you can pick up a half pizza for 9 bucks or a whole pizza for 18 bucks, or you can chow on a slice for 2.25. The next time I go, I need to check out the Apple-Sage Sourdough (baked on Saturday's) & also eager to taste the Chocolate-Cherry Sourdough (baked on Sunday's) Bring cash or hit the ATM down the street b/c it's cash only, yes cash. That's the currency that's green and crisp that fits nicely in your wallet. Just thought I would throw that out there for you plastic heads who are all about the debit card. The way it works: They have fresh offerings in cabinets & you select the slice of coffee cake, focaccia or loaf of bread that you want, bring it the counter & the weigh your share & charge you by the pound. I love this process b/c I know I'm not the only person who sees the cashier grab a tiny slice of foccacia thinking " do i rock the boat & ask them for another slice, then, when they grab a smaller slice that I don't want, I get to sound like a complainer when I ask for yet another..." In any event, you get to pick the slice that fits your fancy & that's great b/c I'm a picky SOB! check their website for the bread schedule so you are not disappointed when you show up & they don't have your favorite selection. Enjoy!
author: Hector G.

description: Found this place using Yelp.  It is amazing!  Looking forward to my fresh bread fix on Saturday.
author: Todd B.

description: Arizmendi is a sister collective of Cheeseboard in Berkeley.  Same great quality stuff.  Even though their pizza is really really good, they have to reheat it simply because they don't get as much foot traffic.  Really solid.  Definitely check it out.
author: Anna T.

description:
Having lived in Berkeley for 4 years, and having loved CheeseBoard... was excited to try Arezmendi's.  The pizza is similar to CheeseBoard... still good, but I felt it was a little on the oily side, and the slices are MUCH smaller than those at CheeseBoard.

The bakery items are pretty good... we had a loaf of whole wheat sourdough, extremely fresh and yummy.

I would have given this 3.5 stars... 4 stars for the food, minus 1/2 star for the portions... but since there are no half stars... goes to 3.
author: Reena S.

description:
The sunshine was abrasive and bounded down upon the city ravenously. Any trace of dew evaporated. The urban streets were a place of commerce and attracted tourism and made me cringe. 
 
Susie, who wanted a postcard of the cable cars or I-heart-San-Francisco, took her hardearned money to all these vendors with glee. There was brunch and champagne already, t-shirts, bracelets from Chinatown, and a shoeshine-- she wanted a picture of this for some reason.  

I suggested we go toward home. Susie laughed so hard but still looked tranquil. Being my best friend, I had seen her drunk and brash before-- so this was Susie being gentle. Though her body still shook violently. 

"I've spent all my tips and all worth it!" she leaped into the air. 
"I know a pizza place. I'm paying," I said.

Susie followed me to the 5 bus, and when we arrived at the edge of Golden Gate Park, headed for Irving St on foot.
author: Jenny T.

description:
On my very first day working in the neighborhood, a customer offered me some advice. She said that every day, at 11:30, I should walk about half a block down 9th Avenue to the green and yellow house and buy some pizza.

So one day, a week or so later, I finally did. I also bought some focaccia. And a cheese roll. Oh, and a shortbread cookie. And then I repeated this sequence for about two weeks.

The pizza was tasty, and way better than more expensive slices elsewhere. The cookie was good, kind of salty, pretty satisfying. I wasn't too fond of the cheese roll. The focaccia tends to be a little bit tough, and really depends on the toppings for flavor, but can be delicious. My favorite so far was the marinated artichoke hearts and tomato focaccia. Yum!

The prices are really good, and though the lines can be long (especially at fresh pizza time), they move quickly and are worth standing in.
author: Vanessa R.

description:
"Make Loaves,  Not War," reads the sign in this small, neat space.

Arizmendi, an impressive cooperative bakery that rotates artisans daily, has lines of people out the door like the I-5 has cows on grassy hills.  For good reason.  Pick an item, any item, because you can't go wrong: foccacia bread, scones, carrot cake, cheese rolls, sourdough rounds, danishes, cookies, muffins and more. 

Loave the sign. Loave the wares.  Loave the idea. 

A fabulous spot to grab some snacks if you're near Golden Gate Park or Irving Street.
author: Chelsee H.

description:
What San francisco Yelpers review list would be complete without a review of the famous Arizmendi Bakery??! 

Let me just say, if you haven't been here then you are really missing out!  

They have a very good size variety of freshly baked and delicious choices.  I absolutely love their various kinds of focaccia's.  I make it a point to try something new every time i come here and i have to say that i have yet to be disappointed by anything i try!  Plus, all the people that work here are all very nice and helpful, make so to ask them their opinion if you can't decide what to get :-)

The only small knock i have on this place is their cash only policy, but for this place, i am always OK with getting some extra cash.

There isn't very much to say that hasn't already been said by everyone on this page, so ill just say, if you are in the mood for a very delicious snack that is absolutely reasonably priced, then this is the place for you.  This is one of the few places in this large city that you cannot go wrong with no matter what you choose! :-D
author: Mark R.

description:
Oh how I love this Bakery!!!! I am so happy to have this place near my place, the food is so good!! I trust the employees, because it's a co-op, and Everything in here is probably good. 

#1 Thing: the english muffins toasted with some butter.....mmmmm
and you should always buy in 3's because it is cheaper that way!

The pizza bread is really yummy too, and the bran muffins. the brioche....oh it's all good!!! Try it all!!
author: Kimberly H.

description: I live in Dallas, but was in San Fran over the summer.. I went to Arizmendi almost every day I was there, and I still dream of their pecan rolls! AMAZING!
author: Kelly H.

description:
I really love Arizmendi's and I hate to say anything bad about the place, BUT after living in the area and going to the place for the past 4 years I do have a bit of a problem with a couple of things: 
1) They don't add enough salt to their bread. For some odd reason this is true of the Cheeseboard and the Arizmendi in Oakland as well. It really comes out in the baguettes. Just a bit more salt would go a long way to improving the flavor of the breads.
2) There pastries vary in quality dramatically from month to month. One day you'll have an awesome brioche knot, and a week or two later the same brioche know will only be so-so.
3) There coffee is almost always burnt. 
4) I'm not a fan of their pizza. Too oily for my tastes, but I'll chalk that one up to personal prefs.
Still, they are pretty good and their cookies are awesome.
author: michael c.

description:
I loved going to Arizmendi when I lived in the Richmond.  Sometimes I'd walk across the park, but usually I bussed it in because I'm lazy   :D

My favorite there is the olive provolone bread.  I have made it to Cheeseboard in Berekley to get it a few times but it isn't the same.

The pizza here is really good too.  Simple ingredients, ever-changing menu.  They used to give you a discount if you showed you took public transportation.

Oh, and I love that it is a cooperative business and I try to support that as often as I can.  Too bad the place is so darn crowded sometimes you can barely move around.
author: J T.

description:
I'm not sure who opened shop first, but this place sort of reminds me of the Cheeseboard in Berkeley.  After all, it's not often that you get to walk into a neighborhood bakery-pizzeria joint. 

Lots of good stuff here!  But IMHO, the CB comes out ahead in drool-inducing slices of pizza and delicious baked goods.  Sometimes I drive across the bay just to eat there...

I still love Arizmendi though--I stop by whenever I'm in the area.
author: Eugene K.

description:
Yummers!

Try their scones... or really anything there. Can't go wrong!

Luckily I do not live close by or I would be here too often.
author: Abby W.

description:
This excellent neighborhood bakery has everything you need: pecan rolls, foccacias, pizza, bran muffins, all made by with love by a true co-operative. 

My gripe is the bakery's floorplan: Arizmendi in the Inner Sunset needs to either find a new space, or take the tables out. Finding what you want, and then finding the line to pay is truly frustrating. Granted, I usually go when it's the most crowded (weekend mornings), but the fact that the tables (it probably sits ten) in the middle of the floor take up valuable space that could be used for the takeout line drives me crazy. It's like they know they kick ass, and have no need to improve because the hordes will always come. 

There's a homeless man in front all the time. I think I will pay him to buy my baked goods for me.

Still, four stars cause their bran muffins keep me regular.
author: Sam S.

description:
i am going to get so fat if i keep trying out all of these bakeries and restaurants! 

on another note, Arizmendi's mint chocolate cookies are ridiculously perfect. i hate eating chocolate chip cookies in which the chocolate chips are hard and teeth shattering. but the chocolate chips in these cookies are soft and almost stay as if they're half melted. perfection! 

i've deducted a star only because i haven't tried anything else from them. the foccacia pizzas look to be of equi-deliciousness though.
author: Regina C.

description:
Fantastic pizza for a great price.  Lovely sourdough crust, good mozzarella cheese (they're are really generous with that), and tasty toppings.  The fennel combos are my favorite.

I usually take home the lite-bake pies, reserved in advance over the phone.  Despite my very, very old oven, their pizzas come out perfect.
author: Tiff ..

description:
I have only had the pizza here, but that is enough. I wouldnt recommend this for those high-maintenance, picky pizza eaters out there, but if you are down to try delicious new pizza combos without complaining, this is a must-try.

Not only do they have reallly interesting and inventive topping combos for their daily special pizzas, but the crust is AMAZING.

I def recommend making the trip out to get a pizza here
author: LeeAnne T.

description: This is a real treasure in the sunset. The various breads are great and I always walk out with a bag full every visit. Please do yourself a favor and stop by when your in the neighborhood and try the pizza you won't regret it.
author: D A.

description:
Great baked goods - breads, morning pastries, veggie pizza.

There are some staples that appear every day, and a rotating menu.  Check out the website.

Brioche Knots are pretty incredible.  Coffee is actually pretty awesome.

It is small, so can get uncomfortably crowded around lunch, or on weekends.

Staff are mellow, but very professional.

Worst thing about this place would be the pushy patrons on the weekends.  Don't be afraid to say 'Excuse me', when navigating the line - we are all in the same boat.
author: Andrew H.

description: LOVE this bakery! I'm so glad I get to live near this bad boy. They open up at 7am and I'm usually one of the first customers thru the door. I grab a "Chocolate Thing" and its piping hot (which I love!). Pizza's are delish and you should also try their cake with salted caramel frosting. The BEST!
author: Fiona C.

description: Went to get some of the mushroom and caramelized onion pizza after seeing the reviews on here. I must say that the reviews didn't let me down. The other breads and goodies they had looked delightful, too, but I restrained myself. Service was great and everyone was friendly! Hope to go back next time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Cookie H.

description:
I absolutely adore this place. Everything is made out of organic flour and it just makes THAT much of a difference. 

Everything here is wonderfully delicious. I love their cheese rolls especially when you get them right when they're fresh out of the oven. Or if you missed it fresh outta the oven, just toast it up and you'll have the taste of melted asiago cheese dancing at the tip of your tongue. Mmmmmmm. 

Their pizzas are freaking awesome as well! I had the green olives, homemade tomato sauce, and feta cheese pizza. The green olives really add a pop to the pizza. They have a different pizza for each day of the month so be sure to check out their menu on their website before coming in. Or, just give yourself a surprise and drop on by to see whats the special that day. 

Our weather has been extremely (and strangely for San Francisco during this time of the season) beautiful and Golden Gate park is just 2 blocks away so why not grab a buddy/lover, a baguette, some pastries, a few slices of pizza, some cheese and enjoy a wonderful day chilling in the park? Come on. Just do it and you wont regret it. Guaranteed by me!
author: Van D.

description:
The only reason this place doesn't get a 5 is the ergonomics of their space. I literally get hip-checked and shoved every time I go in and take more than 5 seconds to choose and retrieve my pastry or bread. I think a slight modification to get that one case away from the door would help. I know its a small spot, and I know they can't control the crazy Inner Sunsetites who fiend for scones; but still, work out the customer flow a TINY bit better. 

I don't even feel like I need to say anything about the offerings. The bread is to die for (and now available at the Sunday Inner Sunset farmers market)!! The pastries are divine and their pizza and random savory starches are all wonderful. I'm not a coffee drinker, but my friends all love it.

Get there before they sell out of whatever goodness you are looking for...
author: Morgan A.

description: Their focaccia is so good! Toppings included ricotta cheese, artichoke hearts, etc. Had the perfect texture and doughiness. Their pizza option is not to miss either. There's no question: Arizmendi knows their bread.
author: Alice Y.

description:
Excellent coffee (best in the Inner Sunset). Bring your own cup for $0.25 off.

Baked goods are pretty amazing - I tend to favor the Corn Cherry Scone and the Pecan Rolls.

Prices are a little high for me to justify daily visits (though, the coffee isn't priced too high) and I'd love to see more bread varieties.

It's very small...they could use an extra exit/entrance.

Pizza of the day is always good.
author: Adam L.

description:
I LOVE Arizmendi! Once I walked in, the aroma from the fresh baked goods put in a trance. I was mesmerized by all the delicious bread, scones, muffins, cookies, and cakes. I wanted to eat EVERYTHING! I couldn't decide what to get! My mouth was watering staring at all the pastries and breads. It was pretty crowded and people were just grabbing everything. So in the heat of the moment, I bagged a brioche knot and a blueberry coffee cake. I ordered a latte and headed home. 

I LOVED the brioche knot. The bread was buttery, soft and sweet from the golden raisins. The outside was perfectly crisp. I savored every last bite. I was full, but had to take a bite of my coffee cake. I mean, it was still literally warm. This was divine. The top was crispy and oaty in texture. The cake was moist and sweet from the blueberries. 

I'm definitely going back to try their pizzas for lunch! I highly recommend this place! But be careful, this place is dangerously good!!!!
author: Denise L.

description:
Arizmendi is heaven.  It's a worker owned co-op bakery in the Inner Sunset.  They offer everything from scones to baguettes to cookies.

I absolutely love their $2 pizza -- it's always gourmet and delicious.  The focaccias are also great.  It's always good to look behind the counter and see what's coming up next, because you just can't beat freshly baked goods.

And their chocolate fudge cake is just obscene.  Seriously, be careful if you ever get one.  Pace yourself, or you'll end up with the biggest sugar high ever.
author: Chris Q.

description:
It's Saturday, and I should go get Apple Sage Bread before they are sold out!  I love their scones, sourdough bread, brioche, olive and cheese bread, and pizza.  My favorite bakery in the city.

Update: I found that they are close between 12/25/06 and 1/1/07!  What a disappointment for me not to get my apple sage sourdough fix.  But I dig the fact that as a co-op they take care of themselves. I recommend that you check their website first before you get in N train.
author: Ryoko M.

description:
Hand made English muffins.  That is all I have to say.  Well, OK maybe a little note on the best pizza I have had in while:  HOLY SHIT@!  

This place has only ONE kind of pizza, a different type each day of the week.  Don't worry though, you will love whatever they touch.  As many pizza freaks will tell you - the secret is in the crust.  Notice you are eating this pizza in a "BAKERY", where they know their shit about dough.  Crust is made from dough...  need I say more?  

Maybe I should also say:  they have fresh, hand made English muffins.  

Oh, me sooooo hungry!
author: Thomas R.

description:
Wow - fresh as fresh can be. When I picked up the coffee cake it was still warm. That brought tears to my eyes. Wonderful pieces of apricot and cranberries. I want more after each bite. Coffee cake fantabulous. 

The chocolate knot was so good and the muffin - it was actually crispy of the very tips and so wonderfully moist inside. Whoever is baking has got this down.
author: Wendy B.

description:
Amazing!
Delicious!
Friendly!
Everything is fresh and wonderful. You can't go wrong here.
Not at all like that snobby place in the Mission....

Thank you Arizmendi's!!!
author: Claudia B.

description:
I'm glad I don't live in the area because if I did, I would come here every day and watch the pounds pack on.  

What can I say?  On a sunny morning it's great to come here, grab a couple of breads and go sit in the park.  I love their olive focaccia, their corn cherry scones, their chocolate things and pecan rolls.  

If you come to the Inner Sunset, don't forget to bring cash as this place does not take credit cards.  If you want to stock up, the bread usually stays pretty soft for a few days...
author: Ixchel F.

description:
Since my last review not more than 3 weeks ago...i have been back to Arizmendi TWICE. =)

Tried the currant scone, peach-blueberry scone, raspberry scone, chocolate biscuit?, and coffee cake...(not in one sitting though haha..i shared...a little :P)

All the scones were pure perfection! Non-dry tasting and full of flavor! 

I think it was called the chocolate biscuit was really bready but did have a fair amount of chocolate chunks. Delicious nonetheless!

Coffee Cake had blueberry/raspberry and tasted moist and sweet.

Highly recommend always getting the scones and the coffee cake.
author: Wendy T.

description:
A true coop, as fresh as it gets for baked goods.

They make vegetarian pizza, a single different variety every day.  This is the best food option I've found when visiting the park.

I'm a regular customer, I return 10-20 times a year.
author: Jonathan D.

description: There is a reason why Arizmendi has 897 reviews. Its amazing. The scones cant be beat. I just moved to Brooklyn and I long for their scones. Dear Arizmendi, can you *please* come out east? If not, let me know where your fellow bakers reside in the Buroughs. We could use some of your excellent baking skills.
author: arusha b.

description:
When I 1st moved to SF some 2yrs ago, my good friend Bryan took me here via bicycle.... I've yearned for the baked goods from Arizmendi ever since.

The pizza is never a let down, the focaccia bread is always amazing with topping like carmeized onions, spinach, pepper, and pine nuts!!  They're rarely ever the same, but you can get some repeat items every so often.

I hate scones, but they have a this Raspberry Rhubarb scone that I will always  GET because even after it's been out for a bit, they're still soft and moist-ish ---- not dry and brittle like eating the stereotypical texture of a scone: like a fruit-flavored stale popcorn bread concoction covered in dry muffin crumbs. 

I cannot reiterate how amazing the PIZZA and the fresh-baked Bread items are!!  I do love the starch groups.   Ride a bike, let them know, and they give you a discount.

super good times.
author: Jake B.

description:
My trip to inner sunset is not complete if I don't stop by and grab one or all of these goodies: 

1) The sweet baked "knot" pastry with raisins
2) The pecan roll
3) The most delicious cookie I've ever had (almond something or other). 

If I lived closer to Arizmendi I would be in trouble :(
author: Stevonne R.

description:
Before going to the California Academy of Sciences, I decided to run over and grab some baked goods for breakfast before going in. 
Found this place by reading about all the great reviews giving me high expectations, I had high hopes and it surely didn't let me down. 

I got the Pecan Roll (2.75), Blueberry muffin, Cherry and cornbread scone, cheese bread, and a couple of the other breads. 

The Pecan Roll was Amazingly delicious, it totally lived up to my expectations. Crunchy on the outside and soft in the inside. So good, it makes my mouth water just writing about it. 

The scones and the blueberry muffin was also delicious but the pecan roll left the biggest impression on me. Cheese bread and other bread was okay. 

The workers are friendly and the atmosphere is nice, its a place I would love to read the paper at while enjoying a light breakfast.
 I would love to come back again if I am in the area.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Nothing here ever really struck me as "amazing." Yeah, it's a bakery. Yeah, it's a co-op (and THAT'S why it rules)...but it's....okay.

Yeah, the prices are good. The goods are good. Everything is "fine."

Nothing ever wowed me, though. Ever. I don't get the hype.

And I'm shocked they don't have more vegan offerings, to be honest.

The way the line is always out the door, I guess I expected more.
author: Danyell K.

description:
I went here for the first time last Saturday, and the pizza of the day was: spinach, red onions, feta cheese, lemon and thyme oil.  This is a fantastic pizza that tastes so fresh with a good amount of toppings, and the crust is crispy on the bite and chewy.  For $2.25 per slice, it's such a great deal.  I'm only giving this pizza 4 stars because I wish there were a variety, maybe just 1 or 2 more to choose from, and I've had better before.  But you can have a great day coming here for a slice of pizza then going across the street to Holy Gelato.

high turnover of food, so everything is fresh and tasty
service is quick
parking is hard to find, metered
author: John D.

description:
LOVE IT!  My favorite has to be the cheese roll.  

A little crowded during morning rush and weekends.  Most regualrs know about the cutthroat competition to get a seat.  Service is mostly good, but sometimes you will get grumpy bakers, and you could swear that instead of a bakery you had just been inside a well liked fictional soup kitchen in New York ; )

Worth the hurdles.
author: Corinne Y.

description: If I could I would eat a slice of pizza from this place daily.  Fresh and good.  Highly recommended.
author: Joseph M.

description: I absolutely love this bakery! It helps that it is within walking distance of my home, my yoga studio, and Golden Gate Park. It is great to stop by on a Saturday morning after my yoga class at Bija and walk across the street to treat myself to either a yummy fruit filled scone or delicious slice of pizza, sometimes I give in to temptation and get both! I often get it to go to eat while I go for a nice stroll in the park. Is there anything better?  Their bread is really good as well, especially the apple sage, mmm.
author: Laura K.

description:
I just tried the bread rolls - I don't remember which ones - they were great. 

I really want to go back and try the pizza.

This place is CASH ONLY and gets extremely crowded - for good reason.
author: Chili B.

description: i was really skeptical at first about a only veggie pizza but i have to say IVE NEVER TRIED BETTER PIZZA BEFORE! i can't imagine im saying this but i prefer the pizza at arizhmendis to any other meaty piiza ive tried before. after ordering just one slice i ran back and ordered another one. the pizza is not greasy and the flavors just mix so well. i will definetly be coming back soon to try more.
author: Nikita K.

description: Foccaccias are divine! Flavorful, olive oil soaked ingredients pilled on high. Mint chocolate cookie is not bad, you taste the rich chocolate first then the clean minty after taste would follow.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Last night's arugula, roasted red bell peppers, manchego cheese, garlic oil, parsley pizza was a delicious combination!

4 stars for their excellent pizza! I only give 5 stars if it included excellent service.
author: Golden Gate Properties I.

description:
Loved everything I've tried so far:

~ Blueberry Apple Scone: nice crust on the outside, dense and moist in the center and not too sweet
~ Pecan Roll: OMG...super addicting with tons of pecans, especially when it was still warm and fresh in the morning!
~ Foccacia Rounds: nice sourdough taste to it
~ Pizza: their flavor of the day was shiitake, portobello and button mushrooms, sesame-ginger-garlic vinaigrette.  Loved the crust and the garlic vinaigrette.

Came here twice today (around 8:15am) and then again in the afternoon (around 3pm) and both times, the place was packed.  The food is awesome and the prices make them even better.
author: Katelynn L.

description:
I love walking. I love taking long walks. I love taking long walks because I get to see more of the city and make me feel refreshed and healthier. I also love Arizmendi Bakery, specifically their pecan rolls. What connects these two? The fact that if I walk about 2.5 miles southeast from my apartment I could easily end up at Arizmendi. How is that a healthy walk if it ends up in my purchasing a pecan roll? Perhaps you can help me reconcile this.

If I don't get the pecan roll (or even if I do), I might buy suburban bread (a dense multi-grain loaf), a vegan chocolate mint cookie, a corn-cherry scone, or piece of their delicious pizza (which is different every day--the pesto mushroom, should you happen to be there on a day they serve it, is fabulous). The only thing I've had from here that didn't wow me was the chocolate cake. I bought it for myself as a consolation prize for surviving a really bad date, but it didn't live up to my expectations.

So, I ask you, can my walk still be healthy if I buy (and consume) a pecan roll in the middle of it?
author: Katie I.

description:
Not knowing I was destined here one foggy Sunday morning, I did not do my proper Yelp recon, and was not fully prepared. Now that I have the Yelp App on my phone that won't be a problem. 

I walked in the door and was completely overwhelmned by the number of baked options and patrons.  I felt a little rushed cause I wanted to get out of the cluster, scanning the goods the spinach foccacia caught my eye, I helped myself and got a small coffee to go. We sat at one of tables outside. The foccacia was good but greasy and quite large. I'd like to go back when it's not a cluster, if that is possible?  I think  a weekday field trip may be in order.
author: Sarah B.

description: Had some time to kill so I decided to get a pizza and take it back to the car that I had parked 6 blocks away.  I got a whole half baked arugula, tomato, garlic pizza that was super delicious later.  The strawberry scone was also fantastic.  I may need to go back next weekend for another one.
author: Seong P.

description:
OOOOH bread! carb heaven! this place knows it! 
Get the Pizzas. sooooo good. Perfect place to counteract any internal purification that may have ocurred across the st. at Cafe Grattitude :)
author: Nicole L.

description:
For me, it is that pizza which draws me in. 

Their pizza is the kind of pizza that makes you *think* that you're eating something healthy, as it's all fancy, what with their leaks and truffle oil. Of course, that isn't the truth. You're not eating healthy, but you are eating good! 

Sadly, I often dash in here to find that they have run out of their daily pizza. I think they do this as a promotional thing. It can't have anything to do with a fresh ingredients and not wanting surplus. It has to be all about keeping me poking my head in...
author: Dixon T.

description:
I don't get it. I keep trying and I never had a great experience. I tried the mexican hot chocolate once and it was lumpy. The cookies were ok, but not chewy.  I don't think they have wifi, but that's probably because there isn't much room to sit around. 
That being said, I love the idea of a co-op bakery!
author: Renata B.

description: Delicious!  There are so many delicious bites here it is hard to decide where to start.  Well first off is the Pizza.  Unless there is something I wont eat on it getting the pizza is a given.  I usually get an assortment of focaccia's and something sweet (their scones are yummy!)..  The people who work here are super nice too.
author: Evan O.

description: loved the pizza of the day, wish i was in this neighborhood so i could eat it everyday
author: Erik A.

description:
So I went here because of the great reviews here.  Twice in one day.  The first time I went was around lunch time, and I was impressed by the atmosphere, and I thought the bread was decent.

I then came back in the late afternoon before I went home, and the bread were pretty much rock solid by this point.

So the recommendation is to definitely buy your bread early in the day when they're nice and hot.

Update: I went back and tried their pizza.  Very nice.  Tried a few other things as well.  Cheese scones were too dry I think and not very good once you're past the cheese.  Pecan rolls were great.  The mushroom + something else foccacia was pretty nice as well (I'm also a *very* big fan of mushrooms).  Basically, the "wetter" it looks, the better it tastes.

Update2: If you're around there at 3:45, they bring out a batch of freshly baked goods around then.
author: Yeh F.

description:
Ain't NOTHING, and i mean NOTHING wrong with this place.

All I'm gonna say is:
- THEIR PIZZAS ARE FUCKING AMAZING

Think about it, your working week is over and done -- the 9-to-5 hidden away for a 48-hour period..the pain and agony of it still clouding your mind Saturday manana,but then... but then!!!

I walk two blocks and there I am.  ***A-r-i-z-m-e-n-d-i***  
How I love thee? - Let me count the ways...

their cookies are awesome
their pizzas are vegetarian and there's only "one type" all day
(think: goat cheese, bell peppers, sun dried tomatoes, garlic, pesto, potatoes, spinach -- and nooo, silly. not altogether -- just various new-combo's every day..)
- their corn-bread-cherry scones are awesome -- and i don't even like cherry-flavored crap.  for this i blame robotripping.  (I mean, err: robotussin) =P

Pizza of le jour & Reed's Ginger Beer == Anjali heaven.
author: Anjali V.

description: UNREAL flatbread.  Don't bother getting the focaccia pizza, go straight to the pizza of the day - delicious and cheap!
author: Vanessa R.

description:
I'll admit the pizza here is so-so. The crust gets a little too chewy on me but it may be a matter of preference and luck of the draw when it comes to toppings since there's only one choice.

What really gets me is the pecan rolls. They are incredible. I know there's butter in them there rolls. It has the right balance of sugar and cinnamon and is completely delectable.
author: Y C.

description: I like how there's only one kind of pizza each day, that way there are no regrets. The one in Emeryville is great too.
author: Kristopher A.

description:
Arizmendi Bakery.

A random trip with a friend to the beautiful Golden Gate Park and we accidentally took the Muni one stop too far. But it was a good thing, otherwise we wouldn't have passed by this amazing little bakery. We stopped by because my friend had heard of this bakery through another friend. Believe in the power of word-of-mouth, friends! 

The pizza was amazing as everyone has already stated. But it just wasn't the pizza, they had this delicious vinagairette on top which made a really good slice of pizza the BEST pizza I've had the pleasure of eating. The cheese roll was also good, but even better heated up in the oven at home. Warning: having a slice of pizza and eating a roll is not for those with sensitive teeth/jaws. Definitely chew slowly and savor your food.

Also, this bakery is not for the low-carb types. You better enjoy your carbohydrates at this place. Then you can go for a run in Golden Gate Park. Mwuahaha.
author: Diana H.

description:
Best scones, brioche knots and coffee cake in the City.  Skip grabbing a seat outside and take the whole crew, paws and all into the park.

I've been spoiled by being within walking distance to Tartine, Mission Beach Cafe, DeLessio, and now Boulange de Hayes.  That being the case, Arizmendi doesn't quite measure up to the long ride anymore.
author: Esther R.

description:
This is my favorite bakery in SF.  It's sooo good.  

My favorites are their pizza, olive provolone bread, and cake.  Unfortunately, it's all somewhat pricey (but it seems all bakeries are).  A slice of (normal sized, vegetarian) pizza is $2, which isn't too bad.  Their olive provolone bread is $4/lb...  about on par with Acme.  But the kicker is their cake.  It's sooo good, but it's $24.  

But it is worth it.  Although my grad-student-salary self will be bringing Costco birthday cake to all but my most favorite people's birthday parties (but the Costco cake is really good -- actually Arizmendi and Costco cakes are the only ones I really like).
author: S J.

description:
I'm so lucky that this is my neighborhood bakery. The food is so yummy! Things to look out for: Pumpernickel bread, English muffins, currant scones, the local honey selection, cookies and pizza of the day. 

I'd give Arizmendi five stars, but it's a pretty small shop and the crowd can be intimidating if you don't know what you want--you can't really linger or browse if it's packed (and it's almost always packed). They also started putting nuts in their bran muffins which is a real bummer because I'm allergic to nuts and I love bran muffins. 

But high five to everything else!
author: Alexis W.

description:
Based on all the Yelp reviews, I decided to venture out to Arizmendi Bakery in SF.  I decided to try the following:  Pizza of the day, cheese roll, greek focaccia, blueberry scone, kookie brittle, and plain shortbread.

Pizza of the day - red potatoes, chives, cheddar, olive oil.  Sounds good, but after waiting 15 minutes it was just mediocre.  Underwhelming.  The pizza was extra crispy thin crust, with undercooked potatoes?

Cheese Roll - maybe i just came on the wrong day?  Tried to bite into the cheese roll but it was really difficult to chew!

Blueberry scone - not bad, good size, edible.

Kookie Brittle - excellent!

Plain Shortbread - Being a shortbread fan, i've had better elsewhere.  Good size cookie though!

Greek Focaccia - Good, tasty, reheats in the oven well.

Overall, it was A-Ok.  I would venture there again if I was in the neighborhood but definitely not my first choice in pizza or baked goods.

I will add that the sister co-op, Cheeseboard in Berkeley is absolutely fantastic!!
author: Ny H.

description:
4.5 stars, really!

their mushroom and spinach focaccia is amazing. very liberal with the olive oil, which i approve of, without it being oil-soaked or anything like that. so earthy, with juicy slices of mushrooms generously sprinkled all over. the bread is substantial and chewy, full-bodied and fresh fresh fresh! the aroma of this bad boy cannot be justifiably captured in words. good, simple ingredients, masterfully assembled; this right here is a piece of art.

ah, the pecan roll. sticky, sweet, straight up bliss. tear this apart and get your fingers all gooey. peace, love, and these layers of bliss in your mouth. this is a sugar & carbs combo done amazingly.

had one of their 'chocolate things' just to check out the simpler items on their menu, and wasn't too impressed. dunked it in hot coffee, and it tasted only slightly better. mine was sparsely studded with chocolate chips too, so that added to my disappointment. an overall 'meh' on this one.

have not had their gourmet pizzas as i've only been here before the pizzas are ready (11.30am, i was told), but their focaccia selections more than make up for it. will definitely try out their pizzas one of these days.

it's a very small establishment, with the display cases lined up against the wall where the entrance is. i felt like i had to hustle a little with my choices instead of really taking a look at the goodies before making my decision, as other people were looking over the goods on display and they were waiting to pick their selections out of the cases too. the line here can get pretty long, so be considerate and ponder only the appropriate amount of time on what to get. also, cash only. you've been informed!
author: Eliza D.

description: Came in this past weekend to get breakfast, and decided on an Oat Scone.  There were scones in other flavors, but the plain-ish one sounded best to me.  Best part for my vegetarian friends - no eggs!  So even my sister could eat one!  :-)  They were very moist and needed no condiments such as butter or honey or jam.  Definitely will come back here again!
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Go for their daily slice, especially when it is the double mushroom pizza. Oh, so darn good.

And yes, I caught the same slice just a day ago.  I so love their mushroom pizzas.  I lucked out and you should find yourself there someday.  I would like to eat there everyday.  Even outside of the reason why you should this support worker-owned cooperatives, this place is the bomb and I mean "food not bombs".  Word!
author: Toome B.

description:
if you only make one pizza flavor a day, chances are you'll make it right.  hence, Arizmendi does pizza well.

I've been by here many times when others were buying food, and finally tried my first slice of their pizza a few weeks ago, and it really was all it's cracked up to be.  Fresh, piping hot, perfect amount of crust, and nice fresh (vegetarian) ingredients.  Their homemade pesto was also delicious.  

My eyes were drawn to all the breads, cakes, and cheeses, but I held myself back on this trip.  But if you're looking for a carb-heavy treat, this is your place.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
Hands down, the BEST place in all of SF, possibly all of the Bay Area, to get baked goods. If you can walk in here, and walk out without a purchase, you are simply not hungry! You hate food! The scones are the best ev-er! I really feel sorry for idiots who think a Starbucks scone is really a scone and not a weapon. Every time I go here (4-6 times weekly) I eat a scone or two, and think I have died and gone to heaven each and every time. Look, over there! I see angels! Yeah, it is the food of gods and goddesses of all fake religions. Tip #1: They offer a 10% discount if you are on your bike, so speak up and identify yourself as such. Tip #2: The food is VERY fresh, and in all reality, made without preservatives (and really, too good to not be inhaled instantly like coke, the powder kind) so don't shame the food by holding onto it over night. Eat it now. I once bought a scone near closing time, and was able to tell it would have been a brick the next day. Much like a Starbucks scone. ONLY downside: CLOSED MONDAY. WTF????????

EDIT/UPDATE:
I always loved this place, and last summer, in the middle of a hot spell, I wandered in shirtless (about the hundredth time I'd done so). It's not like I EAT there, it's not like I am one of the naked Castro guys. I was biking home with no shirt on. I am in and out in mere minutes. The tall snarky grey haired nazi working asks "Can we get a shirt dude?" Being a frequent customer, and seeing only 2 people inside, who are (as it turned out) his friends he was chatting with, I did not see WHAT I was hurting. So I responded with "Is it THAT important?" and got some sarcasm. I think the attitude was unwarranted and while the food is good, I can bake for myself, thanks. I used to spend an easy $10 or so a day here. I am pretty sure that FAR outweighs the 'average' customer.
author: Richard V.

description: This is the most delicious bakery in San Francisco. Their scones are to die for, their cookies and pasties are heavenly. Their foccacia bread items are beyond amazing. They have a different pizza every day, but I've been here several times and have never been disappointed. Only $2.50/slice too! Everything is made right there fresh the same day. Somewhat affordable and I'd be willing to pay twice as much as it costs for stuff from this scrumptious bakery. CASH only.
author: Gabriel C.

description: A pretty nice place to come and enjoy some baked goods and coffee. Of course just like the other Arizmendis, I always keep comparing them to cheeseboard. If you don't compare this place to cheeseboard, then it comes across as quite good.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Arizmendi - I love you and I hate you.

Now, let me count the ways:

I love you because you bake the most delicious english muffins I've every had the pleasure of devouring. I hate you because you shut down for the entire week during Christmas through New Years. 

I love you because of your truly irresistible pecan rolls. I hate you for what those pecan rolls have done to my body. 

I love you because you are so close to my home. I hate you because now I will never be able to move away. 

I love you because you get me up in the morning, I can't wait to enter your door and see what goodies you have inside. I hate you because you don't open until 8:00 a.m. on weekends and bread is not ready until 10:00 a.m.

What can I say after all this? I'm addicted to you.
author: O O.

description: Damn you, Arizmendi, for being located just a half block away from my gym. This place is dangerously good. I come here after work-outs to treat myself to some well-deserved focaccia bread. I know that it totally offsets the calories that I just worked off, but it's completely worth it. Today I had eggplant focaccia! They are always innovative with their selections and everything from the ingredients to the seasoning always seem to work perfectly. There really is no going wrong no matter what you decide to order. I typically order to-go, so the limited seating isn't really an issue for me.
author: Denise L.

description:
Ah yes, nothing like rolling out of bed, throwing on some clothes and meeting up with all my granola friends attempting to fight for the last wolverine.

The breads here are amazing... they have a great range with sourdough breads from sweet to savory. The cakes, cookies, and "others" though... really not so hot.

It's always busy, so don;'t be afraid to drop some elbows to get in or out, remember. it's a competition for those wolverines!

3 best things there: Focaccia, Wolverines, Cheese Bread.

BE THERE!
author: Dave M.

description: The best bakery ever! The parking can be difficult and lines can get long but they are worth the wait!
author: Muna K.

description: The cotton is high. Daddy's rich and your ma is good looking. Pastries here are like summertime. Good stuff.
author: Mandy H.

description:
l Love it. Little cute bakery. We had the cheese roll,scone and pizza.
The berry cornmeal scone is really good. 

You can bring them with a cup of coffee to the grandview park. A nice sunday morning
author: Shenn L.

description:
Amazing neighborhood spot. Nothing bad to say except that it is too small! Since it is always packed you have to navigate your way through the hot mass of people. This is only a problem if you get coffee though, from my experiences. 

Never the less, it's worth the line out the front door to load up on carbs and amaaaazing pizza. The staff is super friendly!
author: dur A.

description:
Oh why, oh why do I love Arizmendi?

Is it because of their organic coffee or their SPICY chai latte?  Or is it because of their amazing pizzas with sourdough crust?  (By the way - you can now pre-order the crust un-cooked & make your own at home!)

Perhaps its because they make the best sourdough English muffins every day fresh or surprise us with new treats like fresh tabbouleh salad (every Thursday)? 

Hmmm ... maybe its just the absolute deliciousness of everything they do from muffins to scones to bread sticks to loaves to cookies!  I could go on forever and never decide on a true answer.  

I'm just glad I live so close!
author: Lisa B.

description:
This is one of the best bakeries that I have ever been to. 

It is a small and unassuming bakery that takes cash only and is self-service, requiring customers to remove and bag their own items., 

The reviews are outstanding and fully well deserved. 

I started with breakfast items, pecan roll, cherry scone and blueberry muffin. This is the first scone that I have ever liked. I applaud their use of corn meal, a fantastic gourmet touch in their pastries. 

The pastries were so good that I turned the car around and returned to purchase some other items for later in the day, a baguette, cheese roll and cheese scones. The cheese bread items were great, surrounded by crispy cheese that is spilled over and with abundant cheese throughout. The baguette had a delicious sourdough flavor that was strong and perfectly executed not difficult to detect like most and the crust was perfectly crispy throughout. 

I will definitely visit this bakery when I return to the Bay area, highest recommendation for anyone who is not turned off by the self service aspects.
author: Robert S.

description: A perfect weekend would include an oat scone from Arizmendi and then a latte from Starbucks.  Ahh..I love the simple life.
author: Be. N.

description: is it really pizza?  it's more of a hollow interpretation of pizza, with all of what i love in a pie flagrantly missing.  people all lined up, standing around like zombies outside eating their oily pizza, made us curious enough to try.  thankfully, it wasn't very good so we will not have to deal with the crowds again.
author: eshwar k.

description:
While Ariz didn't blow me away, considering all the hype, it was damn good. 

Reasonable prices and very tasty breads.  Staff isn't overly friendly but not rude either, which I actually appreciate.  I won't go to the other side of the city just for it, but I'll make it a stop whenever I'm up by the park for sure.
author: Christian H.

description:
It's not good to buy bread here late in the afternoon, like I did the first time.  Got up bright and early today to walk to 9th to grab some of their freshly baked goods.  I grabbed the cheese rolls, the provolone and olive bread rolls, and the scone.  The provolone/olive rolls are weighed... I guess they're extra special.

I went out to be greeted by a panhandler.  Gave him 50 cents, walked off and thought, "hmmm... I'd like to eat some of this provolone/olive bread right now, but I don't want to eat the entire thing".  I walked back to the panhandler dude, gave him half of my prov/olive roll and said, "Here you go sir."  
He smiled back and said, "thank you, but I'm not a sir, I'm just a person."  I said, "well, I just say that out of respect."  We smiled at each other again, and I went off on my way to Art's Cafe.

I munched on the prov/olive roll... DAMN it's some good ass roll.  I then tried the cheese roll... whooooo good too.  It does make a difference when you buy the bread warm.
author: Grace M.

description:
Every time I've looked for an apartment to rent, I will not let myself look at any places within walking distance of Arizmendi. I cannot be trusted around their corn-cherry scones. I have NO CONTROL when it comes to these things -- and if I lived nearby, I would be there every day to get one. (Two?) They aren't like typical scones... they're made with cornmeal, which gives them a delightful crumbly lightly-crunchy texture. Then there are these tart/sweet little dried cherries scattered about in the dough. You bite into the scone, and the surface is lightly crunchy, while the inside is soft and crumbly. You will make a little mess inside your car with the crumbs, if you eat on the go. But who cares. Because you have just enjoyed a baked piece of edible Heaven.

Yeah, they have coffee and pizza and nice staff and I feel good supporting an independent bakery... but really... all of that is secondary to the corn-cherry scones. 

Luckily I currently live a half hour drive away!!!
author: Zoe H.

description:
Start your day here!

But be sure there's a free bench nearby to sit on while you eat your buttery, light, delectable baked sensation with a dollop of Straus yogurt on top. There won't be room in the bakery itself.

And watch out for those starlings on 9th Ave. They're aggressive!

WIth the fresh outta the oven pastry in your tummy, stroll to the park and zen out in the Botanical Gardens - what a great city you live in!
author: maureen f.

description:
How is it possible to infuse chocolate shortbread cookies with the flavor of a rose? HOW DAMN IT!!?!?! It took all my will power to limit myself to two of these heart-shaped cookies from heaven...on top of the white chocolate strawberry scone I ate. Totally worth circling for a parking space for 10 minutes.

It was my first time to Arzimendi this past Valentine's Day, and I was especially enticed to go in because of their V-day menu. Safe to say, I'll go back again regardless of the day's offerings...as the flavor combinations in their breads, scones, and pizza look and smell wonderful! 

The chocolate rose cookies were rich enough to fill my chocolate craving, but not so rich that I felt sick after eating them. And the scone was just how i like them- a bit hard and crispy on the outside, but nice and doughy on the inside..with a punch of strawberry in every bite, but not overdone with the white chocolate.

My only regret was in ordering a small coffee. I was definitely in need of more caffeine than usual that morning, and failed to notice that  their small is a european small...and a medium is an american sized small. Take note, because once you order and pay, the massive line behind you will make you feel bad to go back and correct your order.
author: Raquel C.

description: Really wonderful scones, banana muffin, and brioche twists!! Definitely will go again.
author: AXEL A.

description:
