I've only ever had their delicious baked goods at Rainbow, having little reason to be in the Inner Sunset and never setting foot inside Arizmendi proper.  Rainbow recently stopped carrying all Arizmendi products and I just found out why.

.....apparently, our friends here were reselling without a resale license and got busted.  Good food.  Bad juju.

EDIT:  Arizmendi fights back!  You be the judge!  Here's what they say:

i'm one of the owners of arizmendi in SF and was just reading your review.  thanks for the kudos.

on the bad juju of getting busted for no resale license, with all due respect this is false - while it's true our bakery does not do resale, rainbow was getting arizmendi product from our sister store in emeryville that resells legally.  they stopped for economic reasons.



(I for one can't figure out why an SF store would get their goods from Emeryville when there's an outlet in SF, but what do I know?)
author: Frankie D.

description:
Everday I have to make a sincere effort NOT to let my feet carry me involuntarily to Arizmendi to grab a slice of their pizza-of-the-day. Their pecan rolls, pumpkin muffin and wholewheat bread - my favorites apart from their pizzas. 
Best bakery in Inner Sunset and perhaps all of San Francisco!
'Nuff said.
author: Kalpana G.

description: The staff is friendly at this bakery. The only food I tried is the pizza and I found it to be average.
author: Sargeant T.

description: I finally tried Arizmendi yesterday, despite having lived rather close to it for the past two months. I bought the bialy and two English muffins--all of which were simply fantastic. The bialy was a perfect combination of pungent oniony goodness (and right up there with some of the ones I've had in New York) and freshly baked bread, and the English muffins were easily the best I'd had. MUST RETURN SHORTLY.
author: Finn G.

description:
I mean, the reviews say it all since there are over 900. But i'm bored and I yelp when i'm bored so here's my 2 cents.

Arizmendi seems to be a sister spinoff of the revered Cheeseboard Collective in Berkeley. I love Cheeseboard and fortunately for me, even after graduation I get to experience something similar to it. Arizmendi offers a different pizza each day and they are all vegetarian. I've tried this place many many times and every pizza has been great. Whether it is a triple mushroom pizza with a sesame vinaigrette or a simple heirloom tomato pizza with garlic oil, the ingredients and cheese always work well together.

I haven't tried much of the pastries, but I get the cheddar and green onion scones from time to time.. and they are delicious as well.  

Tiny tiny issues: 
The place is small so if you have a big group, it'll be better to take the pizza to go and enjoy it elsewhere.. The park is so close by so that shouldn't be a big problem! Lines can get very very lone around 12- 12:30. Therefore I feel the best time to come here is sometime around 11:30 because not will the line be fairly short, but they don't bring the pizzas out until around 11:30. This means they'll be fresh and hot.

Also, it's cash only but this shouldn't be a big deal, esp if you have BOA since there's one down the street. I'm going to miss this place when I move =(
author: Jim Y.

description:
Yelp for iPhone is SO COOL!

I'm sitting in a coffee shop on 9th Ave and Irving, and i yelp my iphone to find what's good in tha neighborhood.  One of the highest rated was Arizmendi Bakery. Sounded interesting. So on my way to get the bus  home I walked by there. Then I walked in. Wow. all the pizza things and all the sweet bready things. 

I got a slice of focaccia pizza which was still warm, and a "chocolate things" bun. 

I'm so happy for this discovery. What a find.

Thx yelpers. And Thanks Yelp for iPhone.

 -no lies, just love

-Jj
author: Jacky J.

description:
LOVE THEIR SPIN ON PIZZA OF THE DAY!

 their kabocha and some'in some'in that I had a couple of weeks ago made me want to sing. and i never sing.

lalalalalalalalal - go to arizmendi's and grab a solidly good bite to eat!
author: Stephanie I.

description:
Best scones in the world! I once flew 3000 miles for 2 nights in SF and went straight to Arizmendi to get an Oat Scone (small currants, lots of crunchy whole oats), and a Corn Cherry scone (like cornbread with dried, sweet cherries covered with a layer of sugar?). I like sugar! What can I say? 
I also come here all the time for the Pizza. 
The Cheeseboard coop in Berkeley is and older business, but apparently shared the recipes because they are a co-op and nice like that. However, I think Arizmendi has perfected the recipes and offers even better pizza!
author: Kat T.

description:
** UPDATE** Went to the store finally. Chocolate cake? I had thought it couldn't get better than the cherry corn scones. I was sooooo wrong.

I have never been here to the actual store. My coworker, however, goes every Thursday morning in order to provide us minions with buttery, 700 calorie each mounds of sweet heavenly goodness. I usually eat three. Sometimes I try to be good and still end up eating three. Now, I'm not too picky when it comes to things with sugar in them, but this stuff is fabulous!
author: Ali L.

description:
Four stars, because the cheese bread I had was a three star, and the currant scone was five stars!  I am a scone officianado and when I move to SF I will definitely make this one of my stops for scone cravings.  I really want to try the traditional oat scone because now I know they are professionals at this place (they definitely did not scimp on the cream in the batter....bueno!)  
Clearly however this is not a place to stick around in too long, because it is quite cramped, but for an in and out trip it is perfect.
author: Sheila Y.

description:
Once, I was sitting in Arizmendi bakery, having a happy pizza lunch, and there was a gap in the music, a cd obviously come to its end. A moment of silence, and then I heard the opening of the first track from Ruby Vroom. I looked my slice of pizza, and turned to Benjy S, and said, "If someone wearing Tom Ford walks in that door, I think my head will explode, from everything I love being in the same room." 

Everything has been said, mostly; wonderful pizza and bread and treats from wonderful people. I take the train for twenty minutes just to get a scone. Also, one of the cheapest places in the city to buy fancy cheese, though their selection is (naturally) less than cousin co-op (and my first love) the Cheese Board.
author: Trisha W.

description:
Cruised in and got myself a $1 breadstick the other day....just what I wanted!

Also, I saw that on election day, you can come in and get free Election Day Sugar cookies! But the only way to get them is to show your voting stub! 

I think that is pretty rad. Hey people, if you're not gonna vote on your own, at least do it for free cookies!
author: Audrey K.

description:
You know the place is pretty good for bread and a decent pastry. I don't think its really any where close to Pascal Rigo's Boulangerie's found in various neighborhoods, but since the closest one to me is Cole Valley, I settle for Arizmendi. Except for last weekend when I went there for a tasty something for breakfast and was driven out by the overwhelming stench of their mushroom and brie pizzas at 10 am. Blech.

I'm sure I'll go back, but its really not that impressive.
author: Brandon B.

description:
My wife and I randomly stumbled in this place. We had never heard of it, since we're not from SF. 

It was such an amazing place. We had coffee, pastries, and cookies. Everything was delicious and so fresh!!

Probably the best bakery in the US I've been to!
author: Kaz H.

description:
MMMmmmmm... *everything* is good, and it's worth the wait on a Sunday morning to get in.

Yes, it's a cash only place, but why are *so* many people so bent out of shape about that?  People, there are THREE banks on the corner offering 8 outdoor cash machines.
author: Patrick L.

description:
I was really excited to try Arizmendi's pizzas after a failed attempt to procure one at their sister co-op Cheeseboard's in Berkeley.  I had it all planned out - I scoured the menu and luckily the pizza I had been wanting to try for MONTHS was available this past Sunday.  I can't really make it out there on weekdays very easily so I was glad the pizza I wanted fell on a weekend.  I placed an advance order for a lite-baked whole pizza - shiitake mushrooms, caramelized onions, gruyere cheese, garlic oil, p&p.  P&P stands for parsley and parmesan.

Yesterday afternoon was sunny and lovely (but a bit windy) and I made by way over to the Sunset.  There is NO parking there on weekends so your best bet is to either take Muni (the N line stops right there) or you have to park in front of someone's driveway while you run in.  I deducted 1/2 star for being cash only.  I'm so used to using my credit card for everything that I had to make a special trip to the ATM just for this.

Arizmendi's does smell pretty darn good when you walk inside.  The bakery aroma always makes me hungry and I checked to see what other treats they had.  Nothing really caught my eye, but what they had on the shelves did look pretty yummy.  There are some seats inside if you can't wait to get home to dig into your treats.  Pizzas are $16 for a whole and $8 for a half.  Turns out I didn't really need to order ahead since they had a bunch of pre-boxed lite-baked pizzas already sitting there.  

I was actually pleasantly surprised by the portion size.  It appeared to be around 16 inches in diameter and toppings were generous.  I hate it when pizza toppings are sparse, but this one looked to be chock full of mushrooms, cheese, and onions.  The instructions say to bake for 6-8 minutes at 400 degrees, but I found I had it put it in for a bit longer, about 10 minutes.  Now here is the reason for the other 1/2 star deduction - I didn't like the onions.  Normally I love caramelized onions and caramelized onions coupled with mushrooms and cheese should have been a surefire winner in my book.  But the onions did not taste caramelized to me.  And what sucked was that there were a ton of onions on the pizza, too!  So my experience was a bit anti-climatic.  The crust was nice; I think it was sourdough?  Overall, the pizza was good though, but not as great as I expected it to be.

I really wanted to give Arizmendi's four stars, but I feel the 1/2 star deductions were warranted.  However, I do plan on giving them a second chance.  I'm already planning to visit them on April 13 for the  mushrooms, spinach, basil pesto pizza l so I will update my review then.

4/13 update - the pizza was FANTASTIC.  The pesto/mushroom/spinach combo was great!  It was really cheesy and I liked this one a lot better.  I'm awarding another star.
author: Karen K.

description:
Oh Arizmendi's, how I miss thee!

So enamoured was I of the goodies sold at the co-op, I broke down and bought the cookbook.  I've made countless batches of the currant scone, and have tried my hand at the cornmeal cherry scones a couple of times, but have earmarked a bunch of other recipes to try.

Top 5, in order of favorites:
Brioche knots: a soft bready pastry studded with plump golden raisins and sprinkled with cinnamon sugar. Part of the reason I love it so much is that it's fun to pull apart and consume
Thin sourdough crust pizza: they only serve one kind daily, vegetarian, and it's so delicious you don't mind that there's no meat!
Foccacia: topped with all kinds of roasted goodness, soft and pliable on the inside with a nice cornmeal-studded crust on the bottom.  sold by weight, so it is definitely a great deal!
Cherry cornmeal scones: the cornmeal gives it a pleasant textural heft while the dried cherries' tartness plays against the sweetness of the scone
Currant scone: One of the most popular bakery items sold here.  A great combo of moist scone interior, with a golden, crunchy crust that is liberally sprinkled with cinnamon sugar

The only things I tried that I didn't love were the chocolate things (anything with chocolate chips invariably gets compared to chocolate chip cookies, and is disappointing by comparison) and the fresh seasonal scones.  The latter wasn't as tasty as the dried fruit scones because the fruit burst during baking and made parts of the scone soggy, and tasted sour compared to the sweet scone dough.
author: Janet L.

description: Officially becoming my go-to Saturday morning spot.  Of course, I can go on and on about the pecan rolls, but the cheese rolls were pretty darn good, as were the bran muffins.  I'm always eyeing the scones, so those will be the next thing I pick up.  And I can't leave without a cup of their Sumatra blend.  Perks me up and gets me through my morning!
author: Megan P.

description: This is the best bakery in SF! Everything is great and fresh and the pizza is awesome.  Who doesn't love a place that post on the website their daily pizza menu for the whole month???? Seriously! Amazing scones, cookies and focaccia---nothing will disappoint and service is fast and friendly.
author: Lark L.

description: Where do I even begin?! This place is absolutely amazing. The pizza and focaccia bread is just perfect, and their corn cherry scones are to die for. Trust me, I don't even like scones that much...but these ones are unreal! They use cornmeal and dried cherries, and it's kind of like cornbread on crack (in the best way imaginable). I would live off of them if I could!
author: Ariana L.

description:
I always see this place on my way to work, and finally one day I decided to try. Walking in I immediately thought of the Cheeseboard coop in Berkeley (which was once down the street from my apt) and what do you know, it's a sister coop to my previous breakfast place. The cheese bread was good, albeit a little difficult to break off at times, but good nonetheless. The chocolate thing, well I liked it because I like chocolate. 

I do have to say that I remember the Berkeley one being more fresh and tasty, but this may be due to the fact that I went in at opening time before class (and my visit to Arizmendi was later in the morning, around (9:45am).

I have yet to try their pizza but perhaps one day I will make it back. 3.5 stars for this coop location.
author: Yosie G.

description: The pizza was excellent despite having balsamic on it, which I only like it in small quantities. I also bought a half dozen english muffins made with an organic sourdough yeast that were amazing. The only downside is that there is limited seating if you want to eat there, and it's pretty popular so you might have wait to get a seat.
author: Olen R.

description: I LOVE the baked goods here. The chocolate cake with salted caramel frosting is amazing, the tomato cheese focaccia is delicious, and the pizza, which changes every day, is always a treat. Everything is pretty inexpensive, except the cookies, and the cheese they sell there.
author: claire l.

description: Hands down, one of my favorites in San Francisco. All their baked goods look delicious. So far I have had the mint chocolate chip cookie, pizza, and currant scone. All were delicious and baked to perfection. Cannot go wrong by going to this place. You are sure to find mouth watering treats :)
author: Erelyn A.

description:
Wow!  This place lived up to all of the hype and then some.  Their pizzas are incredible and their bread selection is wide (and delicious!)

I came in here and ordered several slices of the fennel/spinach/balsamic pizza.  It was really tasty, light, and had a great flavor profile.  I really like the model of offering a daily veg pizza.  After I came back from walking around, I wanted to try some of their normal bread- I got an onion bialy and a swiss/tomato focaccia bun, both of which were great.  I wish I was hungry enough to have more, but I had already stuffed myself full of their bread!

The main downside is that inside seating is really limited and the place feels cramped in a way that the Cheese Board in Berkeley doesn't.  Also, my friend's chai tasted harsh and a little off, so I'm a little bit skeptical of their drink selection.
author: Jeff A.

description:
Apparently everybody already knows about Arizmendi, but I have to rave about the wolverine bread--packed with dried fruit and some nuts. I sometimes make special trips across town just to get it.

They have only disappointed me once... when they were closed.
author: Brad C.

description:
Lisa...Pizza!  One more time, pizza and Lisa.  Last time..Lisa, Pizza!  
Hey, it even rhymes with my name!  One bad thing though, they are CLOSED on Mondays.  So Mondays are MY days of rest from those absolutely fabulous no sauce veggie pizzas.  

Also, they make the BEST oatmeal raisin cookies.  Keep in mind, they don't make it everyday.  And YES, I am that girl that walks in and looks for the oatmeal raisin cookies and then make a sad face when i don't see them, and walk out.
author: Lisa L.

description:
WOW! Arizmendi kicks all ass!  Their pizza, no matter what combination of fresh veggies and herbs that they put on it, is incredible.  You must also go for their foccacia and cheese bread, epecially when the cheese bread comes out of the oven.  There are no words to describe how good that is.  It is safe to say that anything you buy in this place will be delicious.  Whenever I am in the inner sunset, I make sure to go to arizmendi.  

They get 5 fabulous stars from me!
author: L A.

description:
I really want to like this place, really really. But I can't get over the attitude dispensed to customers at the counter, and the suspicious lack of math skills suddenly developed by the cashiers when returning your change (conveniently, the cash register only shows the amount of your purchase).

Goods are tasty, prices are ok, but not my go-to spot.
author: Carlo M.

description:
I've only been to this Arizmendi once, they had beets on the pizza, it looked like it was bleeding. I haven't been able to return, and I'm OK with that.
The lakeshore Arizmendi near my apartment has never put beets on the pizza...and they have chocolate raspberry scones on Friday - yum.
author: Julia A.

description: The pizza here is amazing and the chocolate chip cookies melt in your mouth.  They have mastered the art and I have fallen in love with pizza and cc cookies all over again!
author: Blu n.

description:
At one time I bought 4 pizzas at a time for my freezer.
But the last few times they were burnt on the bottom.

And the toppings are SO boring !

And the self serve thing creeps me out, I've seen people reach in with Muni germ stained hands.  ewwwwwww

The worker owners range from being nice/normal to quite the opposite.
I'm kind of over Arizmendi
author: Cinnamon Z.

description:
The baked goods here are exquisite and it is worth braving the tranquil rabble within to get that perfect scone or cinna-bread to share in the Park.  It is also refreshing to see the coop model operate with apparent success (right next door to Craigslist HQ, btw) and with seamless and consistent quality.

mmm hmm them's good eats.
author: Jim W.

description:
I just got the half baked pizza of the day to take home - definitely a quality purchase!  Nice and thin sourdough crust that stays chewy on top and brown and crispy on the bottom, topped with an array of veggies and different cheeses.  You might wonder how this thing reheats, but I'll say that it reheats perfectly and there is no sacrifice in taking this beauty home and baking it yourself.  

It's pretty unique from your standard italian pizza place, but it's really good!  You can tell that the ingredients are super high quality and this thing was made with LOVE!  You might be better off calling ahead to let them know you're coming since it's becoming a very popular dinner item, but get over there and try this homemade pizza.  It's special and really good!  They make a different pizza everyday, so check their calendar to see what's up.
author: Jon S.

description: Cute little bakery that serves wonderful bread, cookies, pastries and THE BEST pizza.  Everyday the pizza selection changes but it is always vegetarian.  My favorite is the mushroom.  As far as traditional bakery items,  I love the mint chocolate chip cookies and the green tea shortbread.  Try Arizmendi!  You will love it.
author: Miss K.

description: I love their pizza! When I come here in the morning before they serve it, I settle for the foccacia bread, which is also freaking delicious. Their scones are pretty good too!
author: Christina X.

description: Yay for Arizmendi's in the City! After a disappointing breakfast at Art's Cafe, my sweetie and I decided to hit up good ole, reliable Arizmendi's for some baked goodness. We got two Zapanos (my favorite thing to eat at Arizmendi's) and dug in later. Go to Arizmendi's for some quality breads, pizza and other baked goods.
author: Sara J.

description:
Oh, how I miss the Cheese Board.  Scrambling during lunch to trek over to the North Side, grabbing a slice and sitting on the grassy median ignoring the cars passing as we eat.  Ah, the memories.

Luckily, we have Arizmendi.  I am addicted to those raisin brioche knotty things and their mint chocolate cookies.  Oh yes, the pizza is equally creative and delicious too.
author: Sun K.

description: Delicious baked goods. Have tried the brownie, carrot cake and chocolate cake -- on multiple visits -- and all were very flavorful and not too sweet. Like the space, friendly staff, too. Can't wait to try their pizzas.
author: Mary C.

description:
this place is good, but people, please! most of the reviews sound like the folks just stepped out of a suburban fog and stumbled onto arizmendi... 

i also not a fan of the over-exuberant use of cornmeal that coats much of the more savory baked goods... i mean, who told the bakers that this was a good idea, anyway??
author: sundari f.

description: I have been blessed to have this bakery close to my house for the last couple years. My favorite is the corn blueberry muffin and the pizza is always delish. It will definitely be one of my must-go-to destinations when I come be to the city.
author: Desiree C.

description: So I dropped by in the early morning, hoping to get my breakfast on. I ordered two chocolate chip cookies and one cinnamon shortbread because obviously I'm watching what I eat. All of it cost a little more than 5 bucks which is alright by me because I needed to put some food in my belly right away. I chose to eat my nom noms inside the place which was probably a mistake. Since it was a nice day, the windows were open and sure enough two bees flew in. BEES. Do you know that a bee sting could kill you? Okay, the probability isn't too great, but seriously, I do not want to die by a bee sting. I haven't seen the last two Harry Potter films yet! Anyways, after I ran out of the place I just ate my goodies while waiting for the bus. The cookies were good and the shortbread was awesome. I'm definitely coming back to try their pizza!
author: Lauren L.

description: A friend had us all go here after eating at Perilla down the street. We were all SO full, but made room. I don't think I would have enjoyed this bakery as much if I hadn't had a "tour guide" to show me how they do things here. Everyone crams themselves into this place and as you walk yourself to the counter, you fill up bags with baked treats. I think I have been back 2 times since. The pizza here is to die for. But my favorite is their bread-sticks. Kind of pricey at a dollar a stick and I wish they had a deal for buying more, but I still go back for more.
author: Jena D.

description:
a wonderful co-op operated and owned by a lovely friendly staff. the shop has a constant stream of people coming in and out, and they mange the line swiftly so the place is never too crowded. 

delicious sweet and savory baked goods. there is cowgirl creamery cheeses, hummus and tabbouleh in the fridge. the daily pizza flavor is vegetarian, and always a must to order be it a slice, half or whole pie. 

believe all the hype in the reviews, and make your way out for some treats made with love.
author: Sheri N.

description:
forget being on a low carb diet.

just give me all the foccacia breads!!!!!!!!!
author: Carol Y.

description: Great bakery! Almost addictive. I could eat here everyday! Love the pizza bread and scones. Very Friendly Staff.
author: dy D.

description: I curse Mondays when I crave carbs and this place is closed...Boo!  I can always rely on a slice of whatever foccacia they have in stock.  Whether it's eggplant and feta or wild mushrooms or even just a variety cheeses...I cherish my savory breads when I get to partake in them!  Combine a slice of foccacia with a cheese roll, and possibly a slice of fresh daily special--oh my gosh..my hubby and I are in gut busting, carb coma.  I say lay on the oliver oil, spinach, savory herbs, and cheese...BRING IT!  I love you Arizmendi, you've made me smile today.
author: elizabeth c.

description: Thank you, guys!  You inspired me to learn to bake so I could reverse engineer your corn-blueberry muffin!  Don't worry, I'll still see you 3 days a week so I can score brioche knots and flatbread pizza.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Wonderful daily foccacia breads. I once had a curry topped one a few years back and have been dreaming about it ever since. 

Their daily pizzas are great, too. 

Their pecan rolls are sweet and sticky and perrrfect.
author: Christine C.

description:
Oh yummmm!!  They serve heavenly scones and muffins.  They use some organic ingredients, but this is not a low-fat, vegan friendly place.  They loud them up with butter and cream.

They are closed on Mondays.
author: Sarah F.

description:
Adding as review #397

I love you in Emeryville, and I love you in San Francisco. I'd love you anywhere because you're fantastic. By far the best pizza and scones ever. Only one type of pizza a day, but it's always delicious.
author: Shannon F.

description: "Amazing baked goods, communally owned and operated. Satisfy your conscience and your palate."
author: Herbert S.

description:
My favorite bakery in town! Everything I have ever had there has been great! My favorites are the cherry corn scones (and i hate scones usually!!) and the brioche! YUMMY! And all the different breads are all so tasty!

All the pizzas are wonderful and always fresh out of the oven! Since so many people hit up this spot, you usually have to wait for the pizza to pop outta the oven (which is fine since its usually only a few minutes).
author: Angela T.

description:
Great baked goods, the cheesy bread is great.  

Come here for lunch.  Like Cheeseboard in Berkeley, they have a daily vegetarian pizza that always tastes great.

Parking sucks but who cares, just double park.
author: Dong T.

description:
Awesome!  That's how I'd describe the Brioche that I had.  This place is great for baked goods.  They even have daily pizza specials for lunch.

It's true that in such a small place where privacy is limited customers will be in your business.  You can tell that these people frequent the bakery often.  Sometimes you just have to put up with the dough lovers.  It was worth it.

Friendly staff, great service and awesome location.  Sit outside and enjoy your coffee with your freshly baked goods.
author: Walter C.

description: The best pizza in the Sunset. No, make that the best pizza in San Francisco. Sure, there's just one flavor a day, but we've never had one that wasn't excellent. See their website to find out the flavor of the day, as well as what breads are available on what days. We never check, as we've never been disappointed. And (big bonus) it's a worker-owned cooperative.
author: Ranger A.

description:
It's hard to know where to start with this bakery.  Great Pizza daily by the slice of take and bake.  Scones, Muffins and breads are all great. Especially fond of the corn blueberry muffins!  Their house Granola is also way above any I've had around sf.

*And the chocolate fudge cake may be the best I've ever had.  And I've had a lot.*

Take the N Judah from anywhere in the city and it's mere steps from the 9th and Irving stop.

For a schedule of what's there and when: http://www.arizmendibakery.org/bread
author: Richard A.

description:
I sometimes stay at my friend's place in the Inner Sunset, and one of the perks of spending the night is going to Arizmendi in the morning for coffee and scones, or pizza later in the day.

But they are closed on Mondays, so they don't get the last star! Since I am not in the neighborhood all of the time, I need to be able to get my Arizmendi fix when I am there. You cannot imagine my disappointment when I walked there one Monday morning a few months back to find them closed.

The pizzas are quite tasty, as are the scones. I ate an entire baguette myself a few weeks ago like a candy bar--if you eat a candy bar with lots of butter slathered on before eat bite.

The coffee and breads aren't incredible, but they pass my high quality standard, and it is the best option for coffee, bread, and a sunny place to sit in that neighborhood.

Oh, and they are all about the organic, employee-owned, fair trade, etc, etc, which isn't too remarkable in this city, but still something that I really appreciate.
author: Lauren H.

description:
The 2ble capuccino I got was pretty good. 
The bread gets a thumbs up. Chocolate things make my tummy sing, just fantastic.
to see super cute staff baking the goodies and running the show.
What a nice environment.

*BEANS: Equator estate
author: ninja M.

description:
I am such a dumbass that it took me until I had looked through about half of the items on display here to realize that I was standing in the Cheese Board SF.  But without the cheese.  O glorious cheese.

So, yeah, it's that same bread.  You put it in the brown paper bag, it looks like there's a cheesesteak in there.  There isn't.  It's still pretty good, but when it comes to bread in this city, good enough isn't.
author: Ficus K.

description:
Excellent co-op bakery!  Best tasting scones, muffins, etc. so far in the City. Even the coffee is good. I wish it was on my route to work in the mornings.  Oh well, guess I'm stuck with cafeteria donuts and coffee.  Only time to enjoy these baked goods are the weekends.

The thin sourdough gourmet pizzas are delicious, available daily after 11:30pm only.  Order by the slice ($2), half pizza ($8), or whole ($16), get a cup of coffee, sit on the outside bench, people watch, and enjoy the sunday afternoon....perfect.
author: Ezduzit S.

description:
Whenever I leave the Bay Area, Arizmendi will probably stand as the business that I miss most.  Unlike a lot of places in San Francisco - even some of my favorites - I really don't think that I could find equivalents of what they sell... possibly anywhere (excepting of course other Arizmendi locations, my persnickety friends).  

The scones are without a doubt the best I have ever had - not overly sweet, moist on the inside yet not underbaked and muffin-like on the outside.  First time visitors - give the corn cherry scone a try.  Trust me.

The pizza is also phenomenal and always unique.  Actually, everything that I have eaten here that involves cheese in any way is about as good as you are going to find anywhere.  In addition to the quality food, the people who work here are friendly despite the crowds of customers and they are organized as a worker-owned/self-managed cooperative.  Why go anywhere else?
author: Josh C.

description: This place is AWESOME ... a little slice of heaven ... and I especially love that it's so close to my apartment and I can get my daily fix of fresh muffins and scones.  They also have a good selection of breads & pizzas, but my favorites are the blueberry muffins and scones.  Only downside is their coffee, which tastes a bit like dirty dishwater.
author: S. I.

description: Nice local spot, closed on Mondays. It's a "savory baked treats and pizza" kinda bakery, not a "frosted birthday cakes" kinda bakery. Their pecan rolls are a terrific Sunday morning treat (but earlier comments regarding the aggressive panhandler are accurate). They sell pizza by the slice (but don't bother buying pizza dough here; you can buy dough at Milano's across the street for a fraction of the cost and pre-ordering is not necessary). I like Arizmendi, but frankly don't think it's worth the hype or the (occasionally) long lines.
author: Miss M.

description: Thank you, Arizmendi.  On the rare occasion that I jump out of bed in the morning, it's usually because I'm looking forward to your scone of the day.
author: Derek K.

description: Tasty baked goods. Can be awfully crowded. You may have to wait in line for your scone. Cash only.
author: Patrick S.

description: Bring cash. Bring lots of cash. It's all delicious, but purchase wisely: prioritize the pizza.
author: Lara C.

description:
Was skeptical of the idea of a "take and bake" pizza......WOW, was it good!

Their web site shows a schedule of the pizza menu. I brought it home at 1 and left it out until 6. I popped it in the oven and bam! This is one hell of a pizza. Quality ingredients and no grease (rare for a pizza with pesto).

Also, they have a large selection of scones, muffins, etc

Go now!!!

***cash only
author: Tim K.

description: Ok I really don't get the hype over their pizza. It's not the BEST pizza it's not even pizza! I think it's more of a flat bread. I'm not saying it's nasty, it was good but nothing to rave about at all. I do like their baked goods, breads are yummy and very hardy and chewy, kinda gave my jaw a workout. I also like the sweet pastries, the chocolate thing, yum! This place makes me fat because I love carbs and once I start can't stop!
author: Karen T.

description: great food, awesome staff who enjoy what they do... if i could eat pizza here everyday i would... and i did... and 15lbs later, i have no regrets/pants that fit.
author: Stephan T.

description:
Guess who's back in the muthaf*ckin' house, with a fat...oh you know the rest! Sorry Yelposphere, I've been too busy to post a review for a minute now, but I promise to be more responsive to my legions of fans (all 3 of them).

Anyways, wifey happened to have a client meeting in the Inner Sunset this afternoon, which meant one thing (okay two, the other being the unavoidable parking ticket which got slapped on our windshield by a surely overweight metermaid): Arizmendi's! A buddy of mine in the 'hood turned me on to Arizmendi's a couple of months back, and my waistline has been hating me (and him, especially him) ever since. For their chocolate chip cookies are the most deliciously sadistic, perverse sugar rush in this lovely little town we call home. Always super moist, loaded with chocolate chips, and hot-out-of-the-oven fresh due to the sheer volume this place moves on a daily basis. They're like the Escobar of SF bakeries (this is a good thing). These cookies are so good, they burn down Nestle's Tollhouse and kick the Keebler elves right in their collective ballbags. And you don't even want to know what they've done to Mrs. Fields' ample backside.

Wifey was a wee bit more famished than I, so she went for the legendary pizza, which didn't even manage to survive the car ride home to the Fillmore. She said the aroma was just too intoxicating and she couldn't wait to tear into that perfectly baked crust, on this fine day loaded with goat cheese, wild mushrooms, and a perfect tomato sauce. She also picked up herself a cookie, which of course I ate after polishing off my very own. Of course this means I'm not getting laid tonight, but whatever. There you have it: Arizmendi Bakery - better than sex!
author: Michael T.

description:
Their pizza will never be as good as Cheeseboard, I don't know why -- I guess it's the whole ambiance of the N. Berkeley location, with the beer and the jazz and the warm, vibrant asmosphere, folks pouring in from and out into the street.

But you gotta love the bread and the whole cooperative vibe, it just doesn't work quite as well in the Inner Sunset.  But if I lived nearby, I'd be here fairly often grabbing a couple slices of pizza.
author: Abendigo R.

description:
There are just too many great things to eat here. The cheese breads are great re-heated with a little beer and the pizza slices are excellent.

I turned a friend on to this bakery and he still asks me to pick up some chocolate things whenever I go there.
author: Chris J.

description:
Man, you take my love of pizza to a whole new level. I used to think that Cheeseboard was my favorite artisan slice around, but this place makes that contention a difficult one to surpass.

Each day a different slice and each day a fantastic orgasm of taste.

Keep it up. Also -- dont forget their East Bay location in Emeryville on San Pablo Ave.
author: Taylor P.

description:
Amazing, have you tried the pizza bread?  Also the chocolate things as they are called are stunning.  It is sooo easy to pack on a solid 5lbs. after visiting this place.  I use to live a block away and thank god I moved or else I would be the size of a house.  The Irish soda bread is also great.  My gram's who's Irish claims that it's as good as what they had as children.  Go figure.

Cash only i think, but wonderful!
author: Nicole F.

description:
Scone-faced.

I heart scones.

I heart scones with their little puffy triangle-ly lumpy shapes

I heart scones with their wonderous carby sweet taste.  


Arizmendi you do them ohh oh soo well!

Recommendations: get the special Scone of the day :)
author: Glamorous D.

description:
I love love love their pecan rolls, their cheese focaccia, their cookies, their pizzas, and their fair trade coffees.    They have a location in Emeryville that is equally good.   

I love those pecan rolls.....   with the coffee... sublime.  

Plus, if you ride there by bike you get a 10% off your order.   Love this place... perfect neighborhood joint.
author: Regi K.

description:
Thank god I don't live in this neighborhood! I would eat nothing but breads and pastries and pizza....

Everything here is incredible and reasonably priced. My favorites are the cherry cornmeal scones and the daily pizza ($2 for a slice of seasonal thin crust deliciousness!).
author: Aimee G.

description:
Hmm... #5 restaurant on all of Yelp? This is something I need to check out.

Scone of the day, apricot-blackberry, was amazing. Everything looked delicious (well except for the pizza of the day, ewww... mushrooms...). 

I'm glad I don't live nearby, otherwise I would be stopping by here all the time.
author: Audrey N.

description:
The best bakery in SF - hands down.  Warm pecan rolls when they come from the oven, are the best.  People that bake / work at Arzimendi's are top notch.

Not a fan of the coffee - they don't keep Equal or Splenda (those aint natural)...and not like there aint sugar in the pecan rolls.

Something not on the menu: Ask for pizza dough to make your own pizza at home.  The dough is well yeasted and has the perfect hint of sourdough tangy-ness.
author: Sheetal S.

description:
Yummy!

The brioche knot is so good. It's soft and the sweetness is just right, not too much but a little bit. One brioche knot will fill my tummy. Unfortunately, I didn't try their pizza but I will definitely next time.
author: Mimi L.

description:
I came here and didn't try the pizza! But I did have a cheese roll which was great. The crispy cheese on the crust of the bread along with the gooey cheese on the inside(after you toast it) and a hint of sourness in the bread itself.  The pecan roll was nice and sweet but not too sweet - beats a cinnamon roll or a donut anyday. It was packed with pecans along with the caramelized glaze which gave it a nice crunchy texture . I also tried a blueberry scone but it was just average to me. 

My only gripe is that they don't toast up the bread if you ask them so you either have to get it fresh out of the oven or toast it at home. I'm going to try the pizza the next time I come here, probably bump the review up to 5 stars too.

4.5 out of 5.
author: Colin H.

description: Awesome muffins, pizza, and cinnamon buns. Never has let me down. Make sure to bring cash. It is a cash only business. But if you forget there is an ATM down the block.
author: Lauren S.

description: A-M-B-R-O-S-I-A. Arizmendi (aka The Cheeseboard in Bezerkeley) brings heaven to earth. All of their baked goods and cheeses are excellent and their pizza is to die for. There's only one flavor a day (always vegetarian), but I don't care since it's so addictive I'm waiting for someone to tell me I need a 12-step program. Get it piping hot or 1/2 baked to finish at home. My only complaint is that Arizmendi is not open seven days a week!
author: M. D.

description:
Fantastic first time experience!!! My girlfriend and I Yelped for some good eats after a fun day at the SF Zoo. Arizmendi Bakery showed up. A bit out of the way from our current route, but with the consistently-great reviews, we decided to give it a shot. 

The majority of reviews were right. It has a quaint, small-town feel to it. "Cozy", but in all the right ways. It has a very friendly, local neighborhood feeling, which I am not used to but love. Fresh, aromatic breads ranging from garlic bread sticks, spinach and mushroom focaccia, tomato focaccia, caramelized onion rolls, and dozens of artisan cheeses greeted us upon entering. 

I couldn't help myself. I grabbed a paper bag, parchment paper, and grabbed everything my eyes had devoured when I first walked in so I could appease my taste buds. I also had a chai tea that was good, but a bit bland. Their specialty pizzas were fantastic. My girlfriend ordered a pesto garlic zucchini rosemary pizza... Sounds like a moothful but trust me: just after typing that description, my mouth just began to salivate. 

The cashier/baker/worker was very friendly. You could tell he remembers and understands the "regulars", which are the backbone of any successful establishment. He quickly greeted another regular, and got their items ready. 

We're not in the Sunset District often, but I still think of their fresh-baked breads on a weekly basis. Arizmendi, we will be reunited soon.
author: mike l.

description: Note that they have a stall in the Inner Sunset Farmer's Market where they do a brisk business in muffins, biales, baguettes, scones and buns with hungry market-goers.  If you're craving their pizza, just step across the street to their regular brick-n-mortar.
author: Claudine C.

description: Amazing blueberry gingerbread scone. Love the daily pizza selections, they are so dense and delicious, makes a full meal. But I shouldn't have given in to the seasonal Chinese new year cookies though, totally not worth $3.75, and they snapped before arrival at final destination. Fail.
author: Julia G.

description:
oh, Arizmendi, Arizmendi how you keep me sated
with such baked goods, can you be twitterpated?

your cherry scone, crumbling in my lap
i like you for breakfast or even a snack
that organic roasted coffee, dribbling down my chin
anything so good must surely be a sin

and those brioche knots, how you make me tingle
if you wanted to date, i would quickly make myself single
for you, or anyone of your brood
i like you so much, i've elevated you above just any old food

alas, i'm sure to become diabetic
and maybe even a bit eclectic
but better to digest than to never experience
i really mean that; i'm totally serious.
author: Miss P.

description: Bread lover's heaven. Their olive focacia and bialy are the best breakfast bread ever! Pizza are great too. Hate Mondays because Arizmendy is closed. The only few things that bother me are the bums that hang out there and sleevless shirts that some male employees wear. Otherwise i would give 5 stars.
author: Larisa F.

description:
OK. I know. Arizmendi throws out a mean cinnamon pecan role. And a bitchin' brioche knot. And, all right, delicious muffins and the best buttery flaky scones. And great, they're a co-op with satisfied, well-paid workers. 
Well, what I want to know is WHY must all their non-sweet items be sourdough based? I must be just about the only person in this damn city who hates sourdough, and I've bitten into many delicious looking pizzas/foccacias/rolls only to realized I've been duped into buying a sourdough product! Now I've learned never, never, never to buy any savory products at Arizmendi!
OK, all hail to Arizmendi and whatever, but would it kill the place to churn out a sweet loaf or two? I mean, I thought this type of place was supposed to celebrate diversity. 
Hmph.
author: Kathleen B.

description:
When I'm hungover and craving some cheesy goodness, I head straight to Arizmendi's for their daily pizza.  It's always vegetarian and ALWAYS delicious.  The last time I went I had an incredible smoked mozzarella and mushroom slice that was so good I had to buy another piece immediately after eating my first.  And this was all before brunch....

I'm not a big sweets person so I can't vouch for any of the muffins, cookies, etc. but i am a HUGE fan of savory bakery goods - focaccias, rolls, artisan breads, and so on.   They pull these off impeccably, the cheese rolls in particular.  The food alone is enough to make me love this place, but the fact that it is a worker-owned cooperative named after a Basque labor organizer makes my heart feel all gooey inside. I heart Arizmendi.
author: Leona K.

description:
Yummy bread and pizza. Never disappointed.  

I love that it's a co-op. I yearn for the simple life of baking. But for now I can only buy it.
author: Lisa R.

description:
This place is the best! I have only been there for breakfast, but it is all good!!!

There is just something about walking home at 8 in the morning with a baggette that is still warm! The prices are great, and it is co-operativly owened and operated, so it is good all around!
author: Bethany C.

description:
Underwhelmed... but I like the grab n' go concept. 

Hate to rain on the Arizmendi Parade, but I definitely prefer the scones at Noe Valley or Tartine Bakery (or Delessio). These were very dough-y like. Although very fresh. 

Also tried the mini pizza and a few cookies (I think) which were sadly forgettable. Not as fresh as the scone. The rest of the baked goods didn't look any more promising. Maybe it was an off day, but it's a tough sell to truck it out to the Sunset for what I had at Arizmendi that day.
author: BroSauce J.

description:
Love it love it love it. One time, I was waiting for my pizza slices, and they forgot all about me. :-( 

BUT!!! when I asked the cashier guy, "what's up with my order?" He was totally apologetic and offered to give me my pizza for free. That's such awesome customer service.
author: sambacat w.

description:
I've never had their pizza so I can't talk about it, but I love this cute little cafe.  They are so cute and everything is fresh.  Also, for some reason I am completely smitten with the local honey that they sell.  I ran out and I am still dreaming about getting myself on a MUNI bus over there the next chance I get

Warning: very limited space.  Plan on going elsewhere to actually eat
author: Alex C.

description:
Great place to get local bake goods and pastries. I bought a bag full of different muffins and scones, all of them were well moist, even the scones which sometimes are dry at other bakeries. I love the whole co-op idea and the prices are reasonable. 

I live in the San Jose area and would love to have a place like that down here. Can't wait to head up to SF to get some Arizmendi's! :)
author: Esther C.

description:
YUM!!!!!  My favorite is the pecan roll and the cheese roll. I ate both in one sitting this morning (don't judge). 

But I wish they took credit cards. And they could use a little more space to handle their many customers..and for a bit more seating. But you can't have it all....
author: Adam S.

description:
This place is awesome! Great baked goods, great (veggie! yay!) pizza every day, good coffee, and friendly service. 
If there's a downside, it's that this location (2 others in the EastBay) is pretty small. Which means you'll probably end up waiting in line on weekends, and there won't be anywhere to sit. 
But that's ok. Go to the park!

ps. It's a co-op. Which rocks, for all the obvious reasons.
author: Chadwick M.

description:
Since I always like to try different bakeries in Bay Area, when I heard about Arizmendi in Oakland, I decided to try their Sf location instead.
The bread is fresh and well made. Daily pizza is good. 
And yes, the pecan sticky bun is really good. (and trust me, it doesn't do any harm to your body. I'm getting tired of people condemning good pastries and desserts for affecting their body shapes)
Worth the trip if you're not in the neighborhood?
Well, you know how expensive gas prices are these days. So save some money there.
author: Angie Y.

description:
Love the breads, english muffins, scones and especially... especially the COOKIES!! I am not a big cookie person, but yikes, the chocolate chip cookies and snickerdoodles have won me over. 

Five spatulas, easy peasy.
author: MaMa Spatula H.

description:
Arizmendi is one of those places where you walk in and want a bite of everything. Great scones, great, unique pizzas. Cookies, pecan rolls. Yum Yum Yum.

They have two flaws, though. Oil and corn meal. All their savory goods, like the topped focaccias, is extremely greasy. Its not a stinky, bad oil, but very oily. They also use so much corn meal on the bottoms of everything to keep it sticking to the oven that I can taste is and crunch on it. As a pizza maker myself I really don't think you need that much of either.
author: Mark F.

description: Fresh pizza, fresh bake goods and a very cozy place.  Although the pizza is not very filling for a fatty like me, it's always so good. I really liked the yam + goat cheese combo.  It's cash only but it's only half a block away from Bank of American and Wells Fargo, so that shouldn't be a problem for anyone.
author: B L.

description:
I won't add too much white noise by extolling how great this place is. The food is great, and I appreciate that they use all natural ingredients and post the ingredients for people to read.
I wouldn't call this place cheap, but I think it's worth the money.
author: A J.

description:
the crust on their baguettes is the best i have ever experienced. and i am an artisan bread epicure. i think.  anywhoo, perfect crunch and softness on their scones.  cookies are not my style, but still high quality.  other savory pastries are definately a treat for your tastebuds.
also they sell a few cheeses, which is a nice convenience.
not open on mondays!
thanks for reading.
author: yayoi s.

description: Great place to grab a quick bite to eat, they have a variety of breads there and it seems to be baked in the same shop, I could tell by the texture and the smell that they were fresh. We bought some sour dough and cheese rolls and a few slices of the spinach pizza, which was excellent. I don't know if they used a pan to make their pizza but their crust is very thin and delicious. Will definitely stop by next time when i'm in town. The only regret I have is I didn't buy enough bread to take home to my mum!
author: Matt C.

description:
If you happen to be in the Inner Sunset, you must go to Arizmendi!

Back in my college days, I would feast at Cheeseboard all the time, namely for their pizza of the day. Sad was the day I left Berkeley, because where in the world would I find pizza as delicious?

Thankfully, I moved to the Inner Sunset, and, more importantly, a block up the street from Arizmendi. Now, Cheeseboard and Arizmendi are sister bakeries and have nearly identical selections. Yes, Arizmendi has a pizza of the day too, and all the pizzas I've had there were great and equally as good as Cheeseboard (my favorite: roasted yukon gold potatoes with basil and pesto). Also great are their cheese rolls, chocolate things, and corn-blueberry muffins. Actually, you'll be hard-pressed to find anything bad at Arizmendi.

Just remember to bring cash with you as they don't accept the plastic.
author: Christine T.

description:
Fresh english muffins, "chocolate thing"s, great bread (one day a week they make a curry roll), solid gourmet pizza.  Did I mention scones.

This place is just pain good.
author: Narendra R.

description:
I can't get enough of this place; I honestly have a hard time walking by and not going in. I rarely try anything but my favorites: the wolverine rolls and the walnut sourdough.  I really do need to branch out, but what can I say?  YOU try taking the walnut sourdough home, toasting it, then putting a little honey on it, it is a slice o'heaven.

 Let me know if YOU can break your habit.
author: Stacey d.

description:
Love the baked goods

Great scones
Great bread
Great cinnamon buns

Speaking of buns - I forgot his name - but he guy behind the counter, kind of looks like Dana Carvey - short - hot body - great smile - yummy body - Did I mention he's hot - Makes all those baked goods seem irrelevant...

Keep the oven on - I'm coming over.....
author: Marc G.

description:
Haven't Tried the Pizza Yet, But...: The cookies are to die for. They make a fantastic chocolate chip that is huge, oaty, and flat enough to be moist without being gooey and satisfying without being heavy. The peanut butter is wonderfully soft and almost creamy (as creamy as a cookie could be). 
If you want a REAL treat, you can always pick up a couple of cookies here, and then walk them down to The Beanery to enjoy with a great cup of coffee...
author: Jo S.

description:
Backstory: 1) My friend Jessica moved to SF some 8 months before I did (or even had plans to come here)... and is a total foodie (and a friend of mine on Yelp), so she has done some serious scoping out of the city for me... niice. She loves this place. 2) Last weekend two friends of mine from HS were in town (well, one from HS, and her girlfriend) ... they went out here while I was working (who does that) and LOVED it too...

Current Story: This AM, my sink backs up (I know, too much info) and I am off to find Breakfast food...  (couldn't cook at home), so I find my way down to Arizmendi and I AM IN LOVE. Cheese roll... wow... awesome... Pizza... yea... rock... 

Only down side... no iced coffee on this HOT ASS SF day...
author: Jordan Y.

description:
The pizza at Arizmendi is so delicious that it doesn't really matter what anything else they tastes like!  and for $2.25 it's a different treat everyday....they have a schedule on their website, but I like the element of surprise.  Because it's always good.

Their other stuff...well, it would be a bit better if they toasted stuff like the focaccia, but for logistics I can see why they don't.  It's also a bit greasy in a way that isn't quite as acceptable as the oily pizza.  But nothing I've gotten has ever been bad.

Also, I think everything is vegetarian (even the daily pizza!), which is a big plus in my book!
author: Ambika C.

description:
CHHHEEEEESE ROOOOLLLLLLLL!!!!

Seriously, though. Your life is not complete until you've had a warm, gooey cheese roll. And the focaccias are delicious. And they have the best coffee in the Inner Sunset. Mild espresso with well-made foam (unlike the harsh beanery coffee with gross, giant-bubbled foam).

Finish it all off with a soft, chocolate chip cookie.

Yummmmm.
author: Lauren C.

description: Ohhhh man...this place is like magic! You will not regret stopping in here and buying something...anything...it's all delicious. They made this focaccia bread once that had corn, tomato, feta cheese, red pepper flakes and sea salt on it...I almost cried when I ate it. It was a truly beautiful moment.
author: Megan K.

description: Great bread and Pizza. They give a special discount if you ride your bicycle there.
author: Jan H.

description: Baked goods, carbs, and the scent of fresh baked bread. This a great place for bread, scones, muffins, rolls, focaccia, etc. The chai tea there is also very good. I have not had a bad thing here. I had the corn and cherry scone, walnut cinnamon roll, olive provolone roll and cheese roll. My favorite is the cheese roll especially when it's warm.
author: Ginny M.

description: I love this bakery. It's inexpensive, the food is healthy, and most importantly, it tastes great. Their daily special pizzas aren't all greasy and loaded with fats like other pizzas. Theirs' are thin and the ingredients are wonderful. Definitely a place worth stopping at for a snack or light lunch.
author: robin w.

description: Good place! People working there seem like they really like what they do. Nice environment, near all the shops in the inner sunset. Lots of different kinds of bake goods. I've had their bialy and a vegan pizza (call ahead), both really tasty!
author: Brian S.

description: love all the baked goods.  the vegan mint chocolate cookie is to die for.  I love the zampanos, my husband loves the focaccia.  little something for everyone.
author: Kim D.

description:
this place is great.  so fresh its 'to live for'

go in and try their pizza.  i don't usually recommend a non pizza place to try pizza but this is very good and people buy it over and over.  its fresh and its the uncommon ingredients used to perfection.

go here if you really like baked goods also.  they have excellent muffins, focaccia(so fresh and many different kinds).  these guys should attend a farmers market and get their secret out but alas the secret is here and if you know about it...its up to you to share it.

the only problem with this place?  parking if you don't know where to find it...especially on a sunday.  

the other problem.  sometimes there is this creep older looking asian guy who is an agressive pan handler.
author: Bing D.

description:
it's not expensive to get a pizza. you get individual slices. the crust is thin and they have a different type a day. 
it's good i plan to go back. except last time i went by, it was too early in the morning so their pizza wasnt ready. then i tried again later in the afternoon sometime but they werent open? 
well ill have to keep trying again. it's pretty crowed.. of course, it's a small place. there's also different breads and pastries too. 
I first went to Cheeseboard and then here. Theyre very similar. o you should try the scones too, always a fun treat
author: Veranna N.

description:
I wish I would've brought more cash- the only thing I could afford was a Zampanos. ): 

It was a good investment. It's a chewy piece of heaven. I'll be back soon, I hope.
author: Angela S.

description: I went with some friends when I visited San Fran a few weeks ago, and this place deserves the kudos it's been getting.  Okay, so I didn't order anything to eat myself (tiny shop, once you're in line, you got to grab something and pay for it).  I couldn't figure out what I wanted in 30 seconds but my friends got a choc chip scone and some other baked treat..I can review Arizemendi b/c I tried each of them and they were awesome!  Please open a place in Tampa :)
author: Chris D.

description: This place is a co-op, everyone who works here is an owner. They bake fine breads, pizza and a few sweet treats. Their baked goods are always high quality. When they first opened I lived around the corner, it wasn't as busy as now, and I got to know the friendly staff.  I have sinced moved to the slower pace of the coast by Santa Cruz but stop by when in S.F. for my PhD program. The staff these days seem a bit stressed and less social than those early days of less business.
author: Johnny B.

description:
Just not sure what the problem is for them to open one in Cole Valley? Is that too much to ask? Anyone?
Two words: cheese rolls.
author: Jonny A.

description:
Can't really comment on the cheeseboard vs. arizmendi comparisons but this place does what it does pretty darn well.  If you're looking for tasty, affordable baked goods then this is your type of place.  

I generally hit up saturdays when they have the provolone-olive bread.  breads in general are good.  I'm not so much a fan of their scones.  I can make them just as good in my own kitchen.  

the focaccias are great.  i had a blackberry-streusel focaccia the other week that i'm still dreaming of.  potato-asiago focaccia was also pretty good.  looking for homemade shortbread that's redolent of butter and everything else that's good?  arizmendi does that as well.  

great place to stop and buy a snack after wandering through gg park.
author: Mike C.

description:
Not the place for ethereal, french style baked goods. No indeed.  If that's what you're looking for, then do not go here. This is more of the lineage of hippie-dippie type cooking and baking, which I grew up eating, so I'm OK with that.

But it IS the place for:
- The best and cheesiest cheese rolls ever
- Delicious "pizza" (I really think it's more of a flatbread since no tomato sauce). Chewy, sourdough-ish crust with a lovely rotating array of vegetarian toppings.
- Great chocolate chip cookies
- Artisan english muffins
- Provolone olive bread
- Bran muffins
author: Celeste S.

description:
Like the Cheese Board in Berkeley, but with less cheese.  Whether or not that's a good thing depends on how you feel about cheese, I guess.  I happen to love it (in spite of my lactose intolerance!) so I'll have to ding Arizmendi at least a star.

Here's a money saving tip -- slices are $2 to go, but only $1.80 to eat in.  At least that's all I had to pay today.
author: Eric W.

description:
This place is in my hood.  It's always crowded which I think is good in some ways...like they go through their pastries fairly quickly, so you don't get stuck with old stuff.

Sweet staff.

Great scones.

Bread/cheese rolls too dense.  Is that why they charge by the pound??

Small space.  It would be great if they had more seating/ space to actually acquire your baked goods.  One stroller in this place and you're totally screwed.  

It is very irritating that people steel pastries from here.  It's a co-op for god sakes.  It's a small business.  Why are grown adults steeling from a small local business.  Losers.

Kinda wish that parents wouldn't let their kids play in the bakery cabinets.  That would make me feel a little less germaphobic.

Awesome Pizza.  Mostly I really like this place.
author: Erinn B.

description:
Daily special pizza....MmmmMmm *drools.

This is one of my favorite bakery. Sucks that I'm not always in this area, missing out all the goodness that comes out from the heavenly oven. Yum! 

Every thing comes out fresh everyday in here. 

Daily Pizza is just an extra touch that sends sparks in the air.  From the crunchy crust to mouth watering fresh ingredients..MmMmmM.

It's a plus for me that all their daily pizzas are non-meat. (I'm just not a meat eater.) If you go on their web page you can see what type of pizza they bake up each day.

Did i mention daily pizza special? ha! gotta try it.. =) 

Just talking about it makes me want some now!!!. But darn I work in Burlingame.. =(. 

I will see you over the weekend... ^o^
author: Ellen K.

description:
I can't say enough about this place. I have to try SO hard not to go here every morning to grab a brioche knot or cheese roll before getting on the muni to work.

The pizzas with the thin crust sourdough are AMAZING. 
It can get a little crowded on weekend morning and afternoons but it's totally worth it.
author: Ny M.

description:
Best slice of Pizza I've had in a while. Pretty much perfect.(they start serving them at 1130)and sell the dough. The smell of the bakery reminds me of when I was little for some reason. 
The line went by really fast and the service was great. 
Good choice of breads and pastries.
CASH ONLY
author: John c.

description: Best baked goods in the Sunset. Suoer friendly and welcoming employees. Awesome pizza, even if you aren't vegetarian you'd love these pies. Great dessert stuff, too, like the multi flavored shortbreads and cookies. Co-op philosophy a winner.
author: David G.

description: Delicious Pizza and Baguettes and Scones...I could go on forever. All I want is a Chocolate Chip scone from them, and I never get it. The Chocolate "things" they have arent so great, too doughy and just not what im looking for. But overall a 5!
author: Adam C.

description:
We were referred here by a restaurant down the street - Park Chow.  Also 5 stars, and worth going to.  See my review of Park Chow.

We dropped in, and grabbed three cookies for dessert.  I had the chocolate cookie with chocolate mint chips.  This was a real CHOCOLATE cookie.  I mean good chocolate, not just brown. I mean GOOD!  

My wife had a blueberry cornbread muffin which she loved, and my daughter had a ginger shortbread cookie.  All were pleased.

The prices were 2-3 dollars per cookie.  However, it's worth it.  You get what you pay for!

There was more flavor in my chocolate cookie than there is in an entire box of mint chocolate girl-scout cookies.
author: Noah B.

description: Got a three mushroom pizza from here and it was one of the best pizza's I've ever had.  They spread the top with olive oil and garlic.  Loved every bite and even loved it after it got cold when I had it for a midnight snack.  Definitely a place to stop by.  Gave it four stars because the wait is a little long but that might be because there are so many ppl waiting in line for the pizza!  Not a lot of seating so plan on getting this to go.
author: Edwin H.

description: I was visiting a friend who lives right around the corner from here and she suggested we get a slice of pizza. It was probably one of the best slices of pizza I've had ever. There was tons of other delicious looking breads and goodies and I would love to try something else when I'm around the way. When we got on the bus the girl next to me said "Arizmendi?" and I had no idea what she was talking about because I hadn't actually paid attention to where we were but my friend said yes and then we had a brief convo about how amazing the pizza was. So obviously what more could I say that hasn't been said a hundred times over here...loved it!
author: Jacquelou W.

description:
Great baked goods -- some you didn't think you needed until you walked in.

Not much seating.  Cash only.

Fast service.   Friendly staff (coop impact?).
author: Brad R.

description: They bake truly amazing baguette, and I am picky about baguette.  Bread is not the kind of thing many people notice, but I have served Arizmendi baguette at dinner parties and people often ask where the bread comes from.  I also love the corn cherry scones, zampano, x roll and cheese roll for breakfast--all great alternatives to overly-sweet pastries.
author: Simona A.

description: You know, here's the thing about Arizmendi. When it's good, it's amazing. But, lately, I'm finding that the consistency of quality is lacking and I'm often disappointed in my purchase. Sometimes the scones taste a little too flour-y and often, they're hard and super dense. Today, I had a slice of cake and it was stale. The good days keep me going back but I'm starting to wonder if it's worth it.
author: Paige B.

description: I brought three pizzas.   I heard it was good.  I brought one in Italy or Greece when I was in the Navy.  Its a healthy pizza because it has spinach, olives, goat cheese, mozzarella, made with olive oil.  Its like 2.25 for a small slice.  It still good because its healthy.  They should put pineapples on top too.  I got there just in time too like 1850 military time or 0650 pm.  Everything in there look wholesome for your body.
author: John F.

description: Co-op baked goods. Whats not to like? Face-stuffing five stars baby.
author: Jonathan P.

description: I don't know what's not to like. The pastries: bomb. The pizza: bomb even though neither my wife nor I like mushrooms but we just skip those days, The bread: bomb. Pricier than an average bakery but hey it's no average bakery. The shortbread is great and a versatile little item for desserts and brunches. The scone of the day, I mean, I don't know how they get the scones so damn moist but they do. It gets crowded at times but the line moves well, never had the coffee here, usually walk down to the beanery a few feet away for a coffee. The lite baked pizzas are great for entertaining, just pick up a couple for a group and finish baking at home.
author: Christopher V.

description: THE BEST BAKERY in SF. Chewy,giant choc chip cookies, freshly made pizza and an assortment of  delectable pastries.All served up with a friendly smile. MUST TRY: Try all their items, I reckon you will not be left wanting.
author: aj s.

description:
I love this Place.

The brioche and blueberry muffin are my Fav...

Not super sweet - just right
author: Torres B.

description: if you like cheeeboard at berkeley, you'll love it here. same idea, same type of pizza, similar pastries, yummy food. also 1 pizza/day. much smaller than berkeley tho. tried their coffee cake, which was pretty amazing.
author: Joyce B.

description: I used to live in this hood and walked by this place a gazillion times, always thinking to myself that I wanted to try some of their delicious smelling baked goods and/or the pizza of the day.  I finally dragged my hungover butt in there a month ago and tried the pizza.  It was ridiculously tasty and I had to get a second piece for the road.  Can't wait to go back!!!
author: Christina S.

description: Have to thank Yelpers here.  As highlighted, cherry corn scone was truly amazing!
author: Woosung A.

description: i just moved into the inner sunset.....i walk by this bakery everyday on my way to work....WOW! it is amazing, delicious, fabulous....i'm glad i'm walking to work these days because i think i might get fat eating all those yummy, bready, cheesy, goodies! MMMMMMM
author: Teri A.

description:
Looking for a great muffin or pastry? This place has the best sweet and relatively healthy pastry selection that you will find in any bakery. 

We always stop by when within earshot of this place!
author: Kantancerous I.

description:
Everything is as good as what everybody says. So why not 5 stars? Cause it's CLOSED ON MONDAYS! You've been warned. 

Yes, that's nitpicky.
author: Fred C.

description:
They put crack in the dough.  No seriously, 'cause I think I need another fix.  I'm shakin' bad...

I haven't had anything bad here, and the service is awesome.  If you haven't had an arizmendi pizza, GO NOW.  Tell your boss you don't feel well and need to go home.  Say you've got menstrual cramps, even if you're a guy like me.  If you're not at work yet, pick up the phone and call in sick.  If it's monday, oh, you're screwed...
author: Billy M.

description:
I've always like baked goods. I like asking friends if they want a "baked good." Sometimes I ask "Can I get you a baked good? Or a cold beverage? How about a hot one?" 

It's like they formed some committee somewhere and decided that if they renamed all the categories then perhaps the chains and big faceless brands might get away with selling us shrinkwrapped breakfasts and standard issue drink units or what have you. 

This bakery has a name that transcends the English language, is impossible to store in your handheld without losing a limb in the process, and doesn't fit into any box or hole, round or square, sealed, ziplocked, or vaccuum packed. 

In other words you just go there like everybody else here has. Find the thing you like that doesnt have a name and which might be sold out next time you go back. And be glad that some things are still there because *they're good!*
author: adrian c.

description:
This bakery is pretty good but the service is sometimes lack luster. Maybe because they are so busy, who knows.

I love the scones, any scone from here is good. The pecan sticky bun thing floats my boat, too. I like the fair trade drip coffee but the espresso drinks here are not good.
author: Pearl R.

description:
Wow.  Setting the bar high, I'm not sure you could go wrong here.  The pizza is slamming, and at $2 a slice for some gourmet goodness, extremely fair.  The chocolate cake was luscious and lascivious.  My partner in crime had some delectable pecan concoction.  All were amazing.
Nothing makes me happier then when a place truly lives up to the hype.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Whenever I am in the inner Sunset, I stop in at Arizmendi Bakery.  I take home a "half baked" pizza and usually end up eating it just like that!  It is sooo good.  The toppings change every day so you never know what you will get but they are always good in a non-traditional, organic way.  Things like fennel, sun dried tomatoes, pesto etc and never any of that pesky tomato sauce!  

The scones and cookies are delish as well.  Try the corn cherry scone.  Piece of heaven.
author: John A.

description: This is what bakery heaven looks like...The best bakery in the city, hands down! Everything they make is phenomenal! Marvelous muffins, fancy focaccia, and precious pizzas rotate daily on posted schedule. Pizzas hot from the oven at 11:30am (pizza schedule on their website) are incredibly delicious, my current favorite being the triple mushroom (shiitake, portobello, button) with sesame-ginger-garlic vinaigrette. By mid-morning, especially on the weekends, the line's usually out-the-door with locals, kids, and cyclists presumably for their carb-loading. Very limited seating (down to one table and two window-side benches, the last I visited!) dictate this as a pickup-and-go establishment, primarily. They're a worker-owned cooperative and give discounts for those arriving by bike! I'm very fortunate to live just blocks from here now, but this place warrants a visit from anywhere in Northern California! Word to the wise: CASH only!
author: Jake G.

description: Fairly good bread but skip the pretty and relatively tasteless pastries. Nice location.Definitely better pure bread choices in Sf.
author: Jeff T.

description:
My first bite into Arizmendi's Sunday special "Chocolate cherry Sourdough bread" was less than heavenly. I guess I had expected so much more since I had read so many Yelp reviews raving about their breads and baked goods. This is over-yelped, over-hyped. 

One could not taste any Sourdough (not even the regular chewy texture, let along the tangy flavor) in the Chocolate Cherry Sourdough bread since the taste was overwhelmed by the very sweet chocolate chips and occasional cherry bit. It's a sweet bread, and one which I would not try again, even though the price was fair $4.99/pound. 

For a chocolate cranberry Sourdough, I prefer Anderson's Bakery's version or even the Walnut Cranberry at Trader Joes. Honestly, Arizmendi was a let down just based on the Chocolate Cherry Sourdough. Perhaps, I would have felt better if I tried their regular Sourdough. I'll post a pic of their bread.

We also tried their pecan roll (a little too sweet, but very buttery smooth texture), and their slice pizza (cold and they reheat it for you). I love gourmet Pizza but that slice was disappointing. 

Honestly, I've tasted better, but it's supposedly a hip small bakery, so I'm giving them 2 stars.
author: Lei P.

description: I hate to do another cost-analysis review, but this is one of those places I'd come to 5X more if it was 20% cheaper.  Pastries, breads, pizzas are tasty, but usually about double (or more) what I'd pay elsewhere.  I mean, if that's what the traffic will bear, more power to them: the only reason this irritates me so much is in their literature, etc. they claim to be "for the people" and are closed on Int'l Workers Day, etc., yet their prices are so out of reach for regular visits even by middle-income people like me.  Example: they used to give a 10% discount if you came on a bicycle...I always ride over there anyway...but since I don't have the proper riding outfit (spandex, etc.) I always had to prove to them that I actually came on a bike!  I mean, in order for me to get the 10% off, they wanted me to spend $$$$ on bike riding outfits?  Does that help illustrate what I'm talking about.  But the baked goods are good.
author: Mike B.

description: Love their scones and english muffins. Wish they made cheeseless pizza or gluten free options, though.
author: Queerie B.

description:
I have a creepy tendency to walk into this bakery, take in deep breathes of air as I look at everything for sale, and leave.

Well, I finally manned up and finally got the courage to grab a brown bag and go bread picking. I was with my cousins, one of which strongly recommended the giant chocolate chip cookie ($2). It wasn't what I had in mind for my first Arizmendi Bakery purchase, but I did just eat lunch. So I decided to go with the cookie and walked up to the register with my, and both of my cousins', purchases. The cashier was incredibly friendly and sang, or perhaps rapped, our items as he took my money.

The cookie was delicious! I found myself having to tell myself to slow down because I was quickly eating the entire cookie. But lack of self restraint left me empty handed within minutes. 

In the end, good service, good food.
author: Virginia C.

description: this is my "go to" incentive for getting kids out of bed and out the door. "Hey, who wants to go to Arizmendi?"
author: shannon w.

description: This place probably doesn't need another 5-star review to let you know how good it is, but I'm can't help myself...I loooove this place!  Carb Heaven.  The daily pizza never fails and the people there are always friendly.  Only downside is that they're cash-only, but BoA & Wells Fargo are just down the street.  Well worth the walk to the ATM in order to get my carbs from Arizmendi.
author: K T.

description: Only have sampled the focaccia and muffins so far, but both were absolutely delicious! A neighborhood asset it seems. Will return & update..
author: J H.

description:
This place is truely amazing for a neighbourhood bakery. 

Most of their muffins and baked goods are excellent- I looove the banana walnut muffin. 
The scones however appear to be a hit-or-miss. My mom had a terrible cheese scone the other day and refused to eat anymore scones from the place.

The pizza is very popular but looks a bit on the greasy side to me. 

I like how they list out ingredients for the baked goods.

My fav. day of the week is Thursday- try their corriander-wheat and spelt molass- they are so good that they can be eaten entirely by themselves, no spread or cheese but just as is. The pumpernickel varieties are excellent as well. yum yum.

I love the fact that they make roll-size breads for single people who shy away from the whole loaf just because of the shear volume. 

The bakery really gets 4.5 stars (0.5 off for the weird scone experience my mom had, and for not making more whole-wheat stuff.... oh how I yearn for whole-wheat sourdough and baguette!!!)

Overall, good neighbourhood freshness and amazing atmosphere (energizing and friendly). Rays of sunshine for the Inner Sunset.
author: grace h.

description:
Good, wholesome and healthy. Three choice words that describe Arizmendi bakery in full. This place is veggie friendly, no meat at all but if you believe yourself to be a carnivore think again. I thought that too, I mean pizza without meat, but they did a wonderful job of creating a huge variety of different complimenting flavors.

They make everything themselves, hot and fresh straight out of the oven. There are a lot of reasons as to why I would not want to be a vegetarian, there lack of beef, chicken, pork and all that, but if I could replace it with the food from this bakery then I would be ok with it.
